Posted: February 22, 2014
												You play as Alan Wake, a best-selling writer. After a few years, Alan is unable to write anything. His wife, hoping to help him with his thoughts, brings him to Bright Falls. Once you drive to your cabin, Alan gets into an argument with his wife and storms out. Darkness consumes the cabin and Alan's wife disappear. He runs outside and sees his wife in the lake and jumps in. Afterward, he finds himself in his car with a head injury, with no memory of what happened after he dove in the lake.The core story spans six episodes, each crafted like part of a TV miniseries. After the first episode's exposition each that follows ends with a cliffhanger, fades to a title screen and then transitions into a plot recap as the next begins.  To finish the game it takes a bit over 10 hours, the story may seem a bit short, but collectible items like hidden coffee thermoses and collectible manuscripts, which tell more and more about Alan Wake's story, offer some incentives to return to Bright Falls. Alan Wake has stellar lighting effects and environmental design that creates an atmosphere to make the scares and thrills more affecting. The game is full of shadows and effects that put the mood of the game into good use.The in-game music is atmospheric and totally in-tuned with the story. The moments of tension were always made better because of the music. Alan Wake is truly a masterpiece. It proves that survival-horror can be very well done with an intelligent story. I can highly recommend this game to all.Sounds 10/10Graphics 9/10Gameplay 9/10Atmosphere 10/10If you liked my review, please feel free to follow me and/or my curator group:http://steamcommunity.com/id/Ov3RT4K3R/myworkshopfiles/?section=guideshttp://steamcommunity.com/groups/orcollective#curationAlso feel free to check out my YouTube Channel: https://www.youtube.com/channel/UC83DYCmrWfl9ttrhX54jmWA

I think the guy deserves it by now.8/10. I carry a flashlight everytime i go out in the darkness, just in case. Thx Remedy Entertainment.

												Alan Wake tells the thrilling story of a writer suffering from writer's block who has travelled to the small town of Bright Falls with his wife to get away from the pressures of being a best selling author. However shortly after arriving in the mysterious town his wife goes missing under unusual circumstances as a seemingly supernatural presence haunts his every move.The story unfolds over 6  (+2 DLC) episodes each opening with their own 'previously on' segment and credits sequence accompanied by some pretty good episode appropriate music. The pacing of each episode does a great job of slowly building intrigue about the mystery of what is going on in this Twin Peaks-esque town and propelling you forward into what's to come. There are mellow, slower moments in which you interact with the town's quirky characters and history as well as tense, fear inducing moments in which you battle against people possessed by the darkness which hunts you down. The majority of the game has you battling the dark presence with just a flashlight and a small array of guns, flares and flashbang grenades. You use the flashlight and flares to deteroiate the shield of darkness covering the enemies, followed by using your guns to finish the job. This sequence is repeated ad nauseam. At first, this makes every combat encounter meaningful and frantically tense and goes a long way towards making the Dark Presence feel like something you have no hope of fighting against in the grand scheme of things. Although this feeling doesn't last long as the lack of enemy variety and weapon selection causes things to drag towards the latter half of the game and the game does little to add variety to the combat encounters other than throwing more enemies at you. As I became more invested in seeing how the artfully told story unfolds, I became less interested in foraging for supplies and engaging in the combat and simply attempted to run past all of the enemies as it became more and more frustrating to deal with the barrage of seemingly never ending enemies.The game is also littered with collectibles; There are coffee thermoses, another homage to Bright Falls inspiration Twin Peaks; An in game FMV TV show entitled 'Night Springs', which is very heavily inspired by episodes of The Twilight Zone; Radio's which provide insight into the town and it's inhabitants through nocturnal radio host Pat Maine and Prophetic manuscript pages written by Alan Wake which foreshadow events that transpire throughout the game, each one fully narrated by the protagonist. The abundance of collectibles combined with the games fairly large environments make you want to explore every nook and cranny to uncover as much of the narrative content there is to see but in doing so you'll find yourself engaging in more and more of the quickly tiring combat as the longer you find yourself in the darkness, the more opponents you'll find yourself fighting against which seems completely antithetical to itself. I often found myself battling the compulsive urge to find everything with the desire to engage in as little of the combat as possible. Despite these shortcomings, I found the intrigue and mystique of the story was more than enough to hook me and keep me playing and interested. Each episode ends in a way that propels you forward and the authorial nature of the protaganist, who frequently shares his often hammy thoughts through voiceover narration, will get you invested in the characters and in discovering what's going on and leave you wanting for more when it reaches the final credits.

content:
Posted: April 28, 2014
												Much human thought and culture has been dedicated to explaining the unknown and thus making it safe. Videogames have too rarely explored the themes of the unknowable inspiring creativity but Alan Wake wants to make the effort. It is a game about an artist changing reality with his gift and facing the darkness, both inside and outside the mind.Alan Wake, the titular novelist, has attained success precious few novelists can even imagine including a downright luxurious apartment in New York City and high visibility in the talk show circuit. He is also a dark, brooding man with only his wife Alice and agent-and-best-friend Barry being his only windows to the humanity in general. A vacation to the mountains and forests of Washington state becomes a nightmare for our hero when his wife is taken by the darkness sending Alan on his quest. The story is central to the game but it is unfortunately impossible to discuss it in detail without posting spoilers. Suffice to say that it is a mixed success. Alan comes off more petulant than tortured and his disdain for people in general renders him unpleasant, especially considering his winning hand in life. What makes this worse is that the writers are on Alan's side and the people he hates turn out to be hateable. The cast has an another Achilles' heel as well in Barry. He is one of those hustling agent types familiar from many, many movies about Hollywood. It makes no sense that someone like that could be on the top of the literary food chain and his career-boosting ideas are inept indeed. His attempts at comedic relief are also a mismatch for the sombre tone of the game in general. Since Alan and Barry get most of the screen time a thickness of skin is recommended.The first and most important rule in depicting genius artists in fiction is always the same: do not show their work for genius cannot be replicated. Alan Wake the game apparently does not approve of this rule for Alan Wake the novelist has pages of his fiction scattered throughout the game as collectibles. The prose is so incompetent that I would have preferred Alan reciting from The Lusty Argonian Maid instead. Sadly these are not the only collectibles for the intense nightmare also has room for beer can pyramids, coffee thermoses and more. You cannot start a generator without passing a QTE test either. The ladders are also something of a mystery: why do I have to first press the action key to mount and then the movement key to climb the damn thing -- with a prompt appearing to tell me what to do? Why can't I be allowed to disappear into the game instead? Alan also has a highly irritating tendency to narrate the events, in effect repeating the things the player is already experiencing or making utterly baffling remarks such as: "I had fallen off so many cliffs it was ridiculous." There is still reason to shut out all this (and a few other things) and focus on the strenghts, the ones that make Alan Wake a game worth experiencing. The forests at night are otherworldly and threatening and I have not seen ones like them elsewhere in gaming. I was most relieved to be allowed to switch off the HUD to complete the atmosphere. The town of Bright Falls also has proud Twin Peaks influences which were highly pleasing to see. Graphics may have some Xbox 360 ruggedness but the nighttime sights are still powerful. The main gameplay element besides experiencing the story is the combat. Alan needs to peel away the darkness protecting the Taken before using his guns to end them. The arsenal consists of a revolver, two varieties of shotguns and hunting rifle which fits the setting perfectly. You also have to reload them one bullet at a time which adds to the intensity of the encounters. The other group of equipment are the light sources you carry, from flashlights and flashbangs to the flare gun which is here the BFG 9000 superweapon it rarely gets to be. Alan isn't particularly nimble either so the process of avoiding enemy attacks, firing and reloading weapons and knowing when to use light requires a steady hand. I found this all pleasurable to do and felt skilled but not invincible after defeating a particularly dangerous group.Alan Wake would certainly have benefited from tough but fair editing. Had the designers been free from the pressures of fitting into the general design of console gameplay of the time and had the writers focused more on presenting questions and invoking mystery than churning out language something unique could have been achieved. But while Alan Wake is a mixed triumph it is still a triumph. The feel of wandering in someone elses dream is palpable in the best sequences as is the intensity in many battle scenes, and the contrast between light and dark is used in many creative and thematically appropriate ways. Those looking for pleasure in nightmare should find some in Alan Wake and I can recommend the game for anyone in the mood for exploring the unknown.

 Alan Wake is a game you should definitely play.If I had to describe Alan Wake in one word, the word would be “Fantastic”. The game is really unique in a few aspects. In the game you play as Alan Wake who is writer from New York. He's not a soldier, he has no combat training, he is clumsy, slow, and last guy you'd pick as video game hero in every possible way. The plot alternates between a manuscript, a dream, flashbacks, and Alan being awake. This can be a little confusing, and I admit after beating the game I'm still not sure what happened. I think this is actually a plus, because it gives you a reason to replay the game, and find the rest of the manuscript. It's almost as if you put Stephan King, & the Twilight Zone in a blender.  The cutscenes, and voice acting are very well done. The story is presented in a series of six episodes, and with each episode you get the “Previously on Alan Wake” cutscenes to lead you in to the next. It's like your controlling a TV episode of the X-files. The game play is survival horror. You always be scrounging for supplies like batteries, flares, bullets, and it typically seems you have just enough to get by. The combat centers around using light from flashlights, flares, generators, or flash grenades to essentially weaken your enemies. The “Taken” are possessed with the darkness, and can only be killed when the light has removed their shield. The scenery is beautiful, the game looks great even on low settings. The lighting and effects, are all on point. The music is a perfect fit, some instrumentals, some alternative indie bands. I can't find anything negative to say about Alan Wake, I enjoyed every minute of the experience, and I'm glad I got a chance to play it. Wait, why are you still reading this? 												Step into the shoes of Alan Wake, a best-selling novelist who is going on vacation in hopes to relieve his writer's block. However, Alan has much more to think about other than his novel when his wife mysteriously vanishes, and pages of a manuscript that he doesn't remember writing suddenly begin to appear; ominously outlining events that are about to occur. Alan Wake is brought to us by the developer of Max Payne 1 and 2, Remedy Entertainment, and was initially released in 2010 for the Xbox 360 before finally making its way to PC in 2012.Things start off normal enough, you're on a ferry with your wife Alice, headed to a remote destination in the forest for your vacation. Your writer's block has been killing your career, you need the escape. You're met by friendly locals who are excited that a big-shot such as yourself will be vacationing near their little town. You stop by a gas station on your way to the cabin that you and Alice have rented, but once you come out of the bathroom things begin to go haywire. However, it's when Alice goes missing at the cabin that things really heat up. She's scared of the dark, so badly that she becomes paralyzed with fear, and now everything is dark; save for what becomes illuminated by your flashlight, and your wife is nowhere to be found.The storytelling in the game is absolutely fantastic, as Alan's inner monologue is spoken as though it is in book format. The game itself is set-up in a TV show format, where once you reach the next chapter you'll be greeted with a "Last Time on Alan Wake" sequence. The entire experience is like playing through a deranged horror show while listening to a coupling audio book. These unique factors only adds to the eeriness of the game, and they also add a different spin on the horror genre as a whole. For the time of release, the environments are lavishly detailed and come with a thick amount of ambiance such as fog, rain, and lightning. Most of your time will be spent in the dark, with only a flashlight to help guide you from one creepy destination to the next. While most of the baddies look the same, their potential of showing up always keeps you looking over your shoulder to make sure that you're not being chased by their near silent presence.Equipped initially with only a flashlight and a pistol, you will later find yourself with more diverse guns to battle the onslaught of evil that awaits. Even though Alan Wake is fast-paced, the fact that you never know from which direction, and when, the devious shadow-people will make an appearance keeps tight tension in the air. Combat is simple, you must shine a concentrated flashlight beam on the shadow-people to dissolve their darkness barrier, and then fill them full of bullets. Paranormal entities are abound, and even inanimate objects become possessed and deadly. When you get overwhelmed, flares and flashbangs are your best friend when it comes to keeping these monstrosities at bay. Whatever you do, your ultimate goal is to stay in the light; that's the only place that you're safe in, but well-lit areas are few and far between.To say that Alan Wake was, and still is, one of the best horror games of the last generation is an understatement. The game was initially a diamond in the rough when it was released on the Xbox 360, though it appears to have garnered the attention it deserves after being released on PC. Graphically, it doesn't even look that dated, it was very far advanced for its time when looking at other games of the same genre and time period, such as F.E.A.R. and Condemned: Criminal Origins. Alan Wake has a flair to it that no other horror title has yet to emulate, duplicate, or even attempt to replicate, it's one of the few games that have been left alone to be uniquely itself. Even six years later, this game stands as one of the horror games that must be played, but not for the price of $32.99 CAD; wait for a summer or holiday sale first.Rating: 5.0/5.0 - An astonishing achievement, this game must be played.𐌕𐋏𐌄 𐋏𐍈𐍂𐍂𐍈𐍂 𐌽𐌄𐌕𐤔𐍈𐍂𐌊 Curator | Group 𐌂𐌋𐌆𐌂𐌊 𐌅𐍈𐍂 𐌾𐍈𐍂𐌄

Posted: October 21, 2016
												In Alan Wake, you play the titular Alan Wake, a successful writer from New York with the rather mysterious sounding name of Alan Wake. Secretly, Alan is a superhero. A Guardian of the Light. When he's asleep, he enters a parallel dimension where he roams the galaxy fighting megalomanical demi-gods and insane zealots with his trusty companions; a talking raccoon and a sentient tree. When he hears his name in the real world "Alan... Wake... Alan... Wake...", he wakes up and returns to the real world. Unfortunately, none of this is in the game.At the beginning of the game, Alan is on a vacation with his wife Alice MacGuffin in a Pacific Northwest town named Mystic Falls. It just so happens that Mystic Falls has a history of strange goings-on dating back hundreds of years; like the time when the town was infested by vampires and the townsfolk trapped them all under a church. More recently, there was that incident where Mr. Muldoon, the groundskeeper of the local school, dressed as a ghost as part of an elaborate scam in cahoots with a crooked property developer, but was foiled by a bunch of meddling kids and a talking dog.Seeking some peace and solitude, Alan rents an old dilapidated cabin on a tiny island at a nearby haunted lake named Lake Placid. According to the tourist brochure, the lake is used by the military as a dumping ground for failed genetic experiments and is full of weaponised piranhas, giant crocodiles, and Miley Cyrus. Even worse, it's also where Microsoft dumped all their unsold Microsoft Zunes. On a cloudless night, one can see entire shoals of Microsoft Zunes gently bobbing on the waves, a shroud of failure covering the entire lake, as far as the eye can see.However, just when Alan thought he could relax, he suddenly wakes up in a car crash with absolutely no memory of the event whatsoever. He's in a car he can't remember driving, next to an empty bottle of Vodka he can't remember drinking. When he goes looking for help, random strangers try to kill him. This is normal in New York City but unheard of in the Pacific Northwest. Even stranger still, he starts finding pages from a manuscript that he's absolutely sure he wrote but doesn't remember writing. One of them was titled "Harry Potter and the Chamber of Secrets". Harry, Hogwarts, and Dumbledore... it all felt terribly familiar to Alan.To top it all off, Alan's wife Alice disappears under mysterious circumstances. The only clue Alan could find was Alice's phone. All it contained was a digital receipt for a one-way plane ticket to Vegas and salacious text messages to a muscular Yoga instructor named Julio. Apparently Alice loved doing the Downward Dog with Julio. Other than that, it was a complete mystery. Not deterred, Alan decides to go look for Alice. By blundering around the forest at night, in the dark, yelling her name.For some reason, a bunch of people known as 'The Taken' want to kill Alan. Why they would name themselves after a Liam Neeson movie is a mystery that's never explained. Fortunately, Alan is not totally defenceless. He's actually quite handy with flashlights. Sometimes he puts it under his chin and tells scary stories. He also waves it around and makes Lightsabre noises. But most of his fights involve him shining light in peoples faces until they get mad and try to kill him. Then he runs like a sissy girl for the next checkpoint.At this point, the line between fantasy and reality begins to blur and the storytelling takes on a surreal quality. Some guy named Billy Zane tries to help Alan. "Alan, you're not a kid anymore, you could get hurt out there," said Billy Zane helpfully. Then there was a Walk-Off and David Bowie was there and some guy pulled his underpants out without removing his pants. It was all hazy to Alan. So many mysteries, so little explanation. That's why Alan Wake is so good.Clearly inspired by authors like Stephen King and Dean Koontz, the storyline and characters are typically clichéd, but nevertheless entertaining. The plucky overweight comedy relief sidekick, feisty female sheriff, sleazy doctor, fruity FBI Agent, and kidnapped wife are all there. There's even a television program in the game named Night Springs that's clearly a parody of, or perhaps a tribute to, creepy television serials such as Twilight Zone, X-Files, and Yo Gabba Gabba. The Pacific Northwest environment, on the other hand, is very well modelled. Some of the background panoramic vistas are breathtaking and complements the storytelling perfectly.The weakest aspect of Alan Wake is the combat. While it's nowhere as good or as satisfying as similar games like Resident Evil 4, it's not terrible either. But it does get repetitive. Weapon selection is limited to revolver, rifle and shotguns. Alan also gets Flares that act as temporary 'Taken Repellant', Flash Bangs that kill anything nearby like grenades, and the smart bomb Flare Gun that's best saved for boss fights.During combat, the Taken are surrounded by shadows that make them impervious to conventional weaponry. Before Alan can hurt them, he has to 'burn away' the shadows with his flashlight. This exhausts the batteries of the flashlight. He has to do this with every single Taken and there are lots of them. Managing two combat resources, batteries and ammo, can get annoying. However, flashlight energy does regenerate slowly over time when not used in combat. The game is also fairly generous with ammo, with boxes of unlimited ammo conveniently placed near some boss encounters.What is most annoying is the lack of a melee ability. If Alan runs out of ammo he's basically screwed. You'd think being from New York City he would have at least picked up some rudimentary street-fighting skills since hailing a cab usually involves some hand-to-hand combat. To even the odds, Alan has an evasion ability that allows him to dodge melee attacks, but it's flaky and unreliable. Dodging is basically just spamming the dodge action key and hoping that it works.Overall, Alan Wake is a good game with its strength being in the narrative. A nice touch is the episodic synopsis that plays before the game begins, "Previously, on Alan Wake...", so you won't forget who Alan Wake is. There's also lots of extra content like the 2 free DLCs, good music, and an in-game commentary. Highly recommended for those who like their mystery spiced with some action.TL;DRA mediocre mystery writer battles supernatural evil in the dark using the world's worst flashlight.

												Draw blood from The Twilight Zone, Twin Peaks, Stephen King, the first Silent Hill, and a teensy bit from Resident Evil 4. Add some original spice here, a little flair there, predate Shadows of the Damned by about a year, and you have Alan Wake. With so many clear inspirational elements at play, and they are clear, you might think this third-person shooter would be a disjointed mess, possibly too reliant on said inspirational properties to have its own voice. And yet, the voice of its titular writer shines through to bring a surprisingly unique and competent game to the table. Alan Wake pulls from horror/weird staples of all mediums to deliver an engaging, if schlocky, story, complemented by satisfying combat and light exploration.Alan Wake is your player character, Stephen King analogue, and hero (?). A best-selling author with a hair-trigger temper, Wake has been faced with creative block for some time. He’s taken to beautiful Bright Falls, Washington by his wife, Alice, to take a breather and hopefully get back in the swing of things. But things take a turn when Alice is taken by a mysterious “dark presence,” and Wake is forced to fight through hordes of light-averse, undead-ish folk. Receiving help from a number of colorful characters along the way, Wake fights to get his wife back from the dark presence and unravel the entity’s mystery.The writing is as cheesy as the acting, which is to say, very. It works, though, in the spirit of Twin Peaks or Silent Hill. Rather than generically scary or thrilling, the game feels more interestingly off-kilter, and certainly self-aware. That said, the writing is just plain bland in several spots, but it’s made up for by the wealth of it. Collectibles are largely dominated by writing pieces in the form of radio shows, short episodes of the Night Springs (*cough* The Twilight Zone *cough*), and mysterious manuscript pages that fill in much of the plot. Out of 100+ pages, a good handful understandably fall short. The radio and television shows, however, are always a treat, and spread out far enough that stopping to listen or watch feels like a nice break rather than a momentum-killer. It’s a game about a writer (*cough* Harry Mason *cough), and it does its best to play that up.The gameplay’s core conceit is using light to disperse enemies’ darkness, rendering them vulnerable to lead-based weaponry. Your flashlight is your aiming reticle, which takes a bit of getting used to, but the slight, default, and appreciated auto-aim makes up for it. Flares, flare guns, and flash grenades are added to your repertoire over time, along rifles and shotguns to take down anything the dark presence throws at you. The one-two punch of light and lead remains satisfying throughout, largely due to the careful balance of resources. Generally, you have just enough for what need’s doing; tension builds when you’re stuck with a dinky pistol and a single clip, but I dare your confidence not to surge when you’re packing 30 shotgun rounds with flares to spare. Enemy variation is limited, unfortunately. There are five types, by my count, and honestly I hesitate to count one or two of those. Still, the majority of encounters are well-designed; I didn’t find combat stale till the final hour or so.Alan Wake has its hiccups: certain major characters are entirely uninspired, the combat can be a slog if you don’t keep its nuances in mind at all times, and the story’s end is unfortunately cordoned off by two DLC episodes. The first episode is a drag, while the second episode makes very creative use of old assets, but through both it’s hard to shake the feeling that Wake has overstayed his welcome. This is to say nothing of Alan Wake’s American Nightmare, Remedy’s short standalone follow-up that is honestly better off watched on YouTube for all but the biggest fans of the series. With all of that in mind, the game is well worth playing. Whether your interest is in classic thrillers, campy horror, survival shooters, or just writing in the medium, Alan Wake has something to offer.

												A must have action thriller for those fans of psychological and eldritch horror. Not a moment gone by without suspense and constant mystery.Pros:-Incredibly rich and detailed world, this is an older title but its eye for detail is out the wazoo-Episodic narrative that really immerses you with fantastic (and slightly tragic) writing-Very challenging gameplay-Creative use of weaponryCons:-Lethargic mobility, and wonky vehicle physics-The game holds you back quite a few times which could get annoying on a 2nd or 3rd playthrough-Lip synching could've been better-The light can be a bit too bright, making it hard to seeA masterfully written and bearing game wrapped within so much mystery that will make you question more well after you've finished it, definitely worth another playthrough (do it on Nightmare, it's not that tough) just to get a full understanding of it all. I really suggest grabbing all of the manuscripts (I mean all of them) so you can really get a sense of how the story developed. The thrill and combat is near constant, with only a few short beautiful vistas to give you a breather, and you'll definitely be grinding teeth now and then until you fully master it all. My tip, conserve your ammunition! Now I understand that Alan isn't exactly an athlete or action hero, but he sometimes moves in a way that is way too slow, taking his time to do his stuff when you're really pressed for time, it shouldn't be that hard to actually SPRINT instead of running just a bit faster for a bit longer, or hurry up with climbing up ladders or getting in and out of vehicles, which takes me to the next point - they're pretty garbage. They're like jello on ice, so be careful when maneuvering the finnicky cars. You'd best leave them alone altogether if they weren't useful for traversing long and sometimes dangerous lengths, so be warned! The game also tends to interrupt your flow by slowing down time to show incoming enemies or pan the camera to locations that are kind of obvious to get to, it's fine on your first playthrough, but gets quite frustrating on your next ones.All in all, besides those gripes, I'd have to say this is one of the best horror games I've played yet, and it shows that a game doesn't have to rely on gore or excessive action to tell a great story and really strike a sense of fear and anxiety in you.Now wake up!

content:
Posted: June 27, 2015
												"He (Nightingale) took out his hip flask when he reached the page that described how he reached the page that made him take out his hip flask."Alan Wake is a linear third-person psychological survival-horror game set in the fictional setting of Bright Falls. The game is divided into six Episodes and is heavily inspired by mystery TV shows, with Twin Peaks considered a major influence. The game follows our protagonist, Alan Wake, as he tries to uncover and solve the events behind his wife's enigmatic disappearance whilst on vacation to the, seemingly picturesque and calm, town of Bright Falls. Gameplay is fairly simple. The protagonist is armed with a mandatory flashlight and, depending upon availability, an assortment of weapons ranging from a revolver, shotgun, rifle, flare gun, flares and flash grenades. Most of the game takes place in the dark so the flashlight aids in navigating the environment as well as battling the Taken, who are your foes in the darkness. So the flashlight and a weapon of your choice are enough to ward off enemies, which range from blade and chainsaw-wielding foes to poltergeists that throw stuff at you. There are instances when you can drive a car to move around but those segments are completely optional and thus, can be skipped. Ammo is not plentiful so it's up to the player to judge when to take enemies head-on or settle for evasive action. Light is your best friend in the dark. In addition to the usual ammo boxes, fluorescent paint directional cues also lead you to essential supply caches. Exploration rewards you with supplies and also enhances story progression but there's a certain risk involved as foes can jump at you from the dark at any instance. Manuscripts scattered across the environment complement the story and are considered essential towards understanding the intricacies of the plot.Remedy outdid themselves by designing Bright Falls. It's a stunning, albeit grim, town and the attention to detail is amazing. So it comes as a bit of a let-down that the game isn't open-world because Bright Falls is one place that deserves to be explored thoroughly. The story character voice-overs are brilliant and it almost feels like one is watching a mini-TV show. The writing is spectacular; not unexpected for a Sam Lake game. Alan Wake happens to be the most atmospheric game I've played in a long time. The game really pulls you in after the first few episodes. Although missions tend to get tedious because you're forever warding off enemies and/or finding alternate routes to the objective. There are also a few glaring plot holes and characters whose fate was left dangling mid-air. But thankfully, the story is gripping and the presentation and production values are top notch.

content:
Posted: November 25, 2016
***Contains the 2 DLCs "The Signal" and "The Writer"***As always this review is just my own opinion and what I think about this game. If you notice any mistakes I made (apart from grammar mistakes) feel free to report them in the comments.Story:Did you ever read a Stephen King novel in your life? No? Then you should. Yes? Then some aspects of this games story may remind you of his works. The story focuses on writer and husband Alan Wake, who after a severe writer's block decided to leave the bustling city for a long holiday with his wife Alice. Together they visit the small town of Bright Falls, with its old and rural look, including odd townfolk. Telling any more about the story would (in my mind) spoil it for you, just know that things soon take a dark and mysterious turn, all the while letting the player guess about what is really happening until the end. This and the plot twists throughout the game, combined with a storytelling like you would read a good book make for one of the best stories I've ever encountered.Gameplay:Again, actually telling you about the gameplay would spoil some of the story for you, so this will be rather short. The combat system and view is third-person. You get various weapons, like a revolver or a hunting rifle, which you will need to combine with the light of your flashlight to fight off your enemies and make it through each chapter. Darkness and light also play an important role, both story and gameplay wise, since light serves as protection from the dark and even heal Alan. While this system is pretty fun at first, it might get rather boring for you after some time, even though the game gives you new stuff if you progress. For the collectors among you, there are different things to collect, like Coffee Thermoses (ever writers friend) and manuscript pages, which tell part of the story. The levels might sometimes feel repetetive (lots of forests) and linear, but deliver a creepy and rustic atmosphere.Graphics:Alan Wake was made in 2010, but even then the graphics seemed a bit outdated. Some of the textures seem a bit unsharp or muddy. The faces could be a bit more detailed. But what is really impressive is the way the game plays with light effects combined with darkness. Your flashlight, a small light pole in the distance, or even light from a window feel somehow alive and give the player a feeling of safety. The game also runs smoothly and without problems, at least in my experience.Sound:Never in my life would I have thought that a video game would introduce me to a band that I would listen to even years after. Alan Wake did exactly that. The "Poets of the Fall", or "Old Gods of Asgard" as they are called in-game, are a great and underappreciated Alternative Rock band with a charm like no other. Working together closely with Remedy (Alan Wakes developer), they brought forth songs like "Children of the Elder God" or "The Poet and the Muse, which fit great into the setting and story. On the other hand and more on the soundtrack side is composer Petri Alanko, who captures the atmosphere and feeling of Alan Wake perfectly with his genius tracks.Content:Depending on how much you explore and how fast and skilled you are, the game may take about 10-20 hours, 25-30 for completionists. The two DLCs offer about 2 extra hours each. The game also leaves some manuscript pages unobtainable while playing for the first time, these can only be collected in Nightmare mode. Since the game itsself is rather linear, the time won't strech too far. (I've played through it multiple times though, since its one of my favourites.Multiplayer:None.Conclusion:Alan Wake is a third-person mystery thriller that scores with an incredible story and soundtrack, that captures the hearts of those who play it. Even if some of the graphic features lack in looks and the gameplay is not too special, these things are not what make Alan Wake one of my all-time favourites. A greatly underestimated and overlooked game, which rewards anyone who loves a good story, well written characters and coffee thermoses.For he did not know; That beyond the lake he called home; Lies a deeper, darker ocean green; Where waves are both wilder and more serene. To its ports I've been.

Posted: September 1, 2015
												I only picked up this game when it was on sale for like $4 and took a year or so before I actually got around to playing it.I'm sorry I didn't find out about this game when I came out and that I took so long to play it after buying it, because it's amazing.First of all, it's heavily influenced by a bunch of♥♥♥♥♥♥that I like, mostly Stephen King, and Twin Peaks. Particularly Stephen King, although other literary references are dropped here and there. The main plot is that you are a deeply troubled writer on vacation with your wife in a quaint mountain town. Pretty quickly you realize that things are going on in this town that are quite strange, the supernatural is afoot, and pretty quickly your wife disappears and you are on the run for your life from the dark, spectral inhabitants of the town. 2SPOOPY4ME!But seriously though, although some of the plot points are a bit cheesy, the core of the story is very good. You spend the whole game fighting dark creatures while traveling through the town, and the whole time, you question whether or not what you're experiencing is "real" or Alan Wake descending into insanity. It's a theme the game comes back to quite a bit, which is also indicative of the Stephen King influence.And in the end *SPOILER*after all this questing to retrieve your stolen wife, you end up having to sacrifice yourself to do so, by trapping yourself in the dark world in which she was being held. It ends the game on a really good note in my opinion, because it shows the dedication of Alan Wake's character, and allows him more character building in the American Nightmare storyline and the extra chapters. *END SPOILER*The game is sort of hard, the shooting mechanics are kinda clunky, and enemies can spawn infinitely in sort of areas, meaning if you get trapped in a bad spot, running low on ammo can mean getting stuck in that spot of the game since there are no melee options or non-firearm based attacks.Using light as a resource is a good mechanic, but it's also sort of poorly implemented. Overall, the game has a lot of good ideas but the developers were'nt really sure whether they wanted this to be a shooter or a horror game.The storyline is really good though, and it is a unique experience that I thoroughly enjoyed.

												Alan Wake is an episodic, third person shooter with traces of psychological horror elements at times. I like this game a lot. The episodic format makes it easy to take breaks between play sessions (each "episode" even starts with a "...previously, on Alan Wake"). The graphics are verry pretty and looks like the team really put time and effort in porting the game. Same can be said for the sound effects and the music.Gameplay wise, it's a TPS with an interesting mechanic - the enemies are defeted by first shining a light on them (Alan is using a battery powered flashlight), destroying the "darkness" surrounding the enemies and only after that you are able to shoot and destroy them.The part I enjoyed the most was the story - it feels like an actual TV show, but with a great plot and plot twists. It can take a bit of time to chew through all the info you are presented with at times but it all makes sense and leaves you longing for more.All in all, this is a good game and I highly recommend it.

												Alan Wake is a third person action/thriller game, which eases in the direction of horror without ever completely descending into it. Despite not being released in an episodic format, the game is laid out in a series of "episodes" complete with credits and an ending theme which I feel needs to be noted because each one is excellently chosen - I wish all the licensed music could have been on the soundtrack.Combat controls aren't bad, but aren't great - they act to make the game a little more stilted than it otherwise would be, and definitely lends the combat to feel more like padding between cutscenes instead of something interesting into the gameplay itself.The story is more "unsettling" than outright creepy/horror, but if you're easily scared it might be best to skip it.Graphics hold up excellently, and the two DLC chapters which follow the original game are.....weird. Good, but weird.All in all, the game is VERY solid, and the atmosphere of the game is incredible. Highly recommended, and I'd also give a nod toward getting the collector's edition so you get the soundtrack, as well. The soundtrack is dissimilar to many game soundtracks in that there are vocal tracks as well, and it's very, very good.Heck, just buy the franchise pack - American Nightmare is even better than the original game (if a tad short), and the combat controls were tightened up to the point where the combat is quite fun.

content:
Posted: March 23, 2014
												Alan Wake is a third person action/thriller game, which eases in the direction of horror without ever completely descending into it. Despite not being released in an episodic format, the game is laid out in a series of "episodes" complete with credits and an ending theme which I feel needs to be noted because each one is excellently chosen - I wish all the licensed music could have been on the soundtrack.Combat controls aren't bad, but aren't great - they act to make the game a little more stilted than it otherwise would be, and definitely lends the combat to feel more like padding between cutscenes instead of something interesting into the gameplay itself.The story is more "unsettling" than outright creepy/horror, but if you're easily scared it might be best to skip it.Graphics hold up excellently, and the two DLC chapters which follow the original game are.....weird. Good, but weird.All in all, the game is VERY solid, and the atmosphere of the game is incredible. Highly recommended, and I'd also give a nod toward getting the collector's edition so you get the soundtrack, as well. The soundtrack is dissimilar to many game soundtracks in that there are vocal tracks as well, and it's very, very good.Heck, just buy the franchise pack - American Nightmare is even better than the original game (if a tad short), and the combat controls were tightened up to the point where the combat is quite fun.

content:
Posted: February 5, 2014
												The six missions begin and end as true-to-form episodic television, with "Previously on Alan Wake..." intro montages and cliffhanger endings, not to mention the great soundtrack to add authenticity. Graphics are remarkably mint (demonstrating the power of a good console port). Writing, pacing and plotlines are superb, albeit a tad predictable for anyone vaguely familiar with Stephen Kings works but none the less remain captivating, dark and edgey. There are no groundbreaking concepts in tow- the game creators seemingly show respect to the adage of not fixing that which is not broke, and the game is better for it.In a vague nutshell, you spend much of the time talking in soliloquy, trying to find your missing wife, while ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ your pants as you flee from axe wielding men hellbent on killing you, in a dark forest, with limited weapons/ammo and only a torch to keep them at bay. And every moment is a terrifying hoot.A video game, a horror novel and a tv show. Alan Wake is all of these.8/10

content:
Posted: February 3, 2014
												Steven King gets his own video game!!!! No, not really, actually the story told by this game is a lot better than much of the recent releases by King, but he does get a reference or two in the game. All in all the setting is spot on, the fighting style can get a bit repetitive (shine light to remove immunity, shoot weapon), but they give you enough options to keep it interesting. Not to mention this game doesn't work well with bad accuracy. Your character is extremely squishy and can often get put into a stun lock when there are multiple enemies around, so some strategy is required for the pacing of which enemies you kill/stun and when. Range is your best friend in the game - second only to light, and while the game doesn't have any "cover" mechanics, if you are clever you can make your own. Ammo conservation is a major aspect of the game, but minimalists can still finish out an act with a stockpile of ammo. All in all, I'd say 9/10. Wake is a fantastic character, thrown into chaos; he goes with the flow with a sense of natural disbelief. If he weren't so driven to save his wife, he would go batshit crazy extremely early in the story. Even the semi-comic relief character Barry has a nice balance of annoyance and "this guy could really possibly be my best friend", all the while surprisingly making you hope he doesn't get killed the whole way through. With nods to various classic psycho-horror icons like "The Twilight Zone" in the games very own "Night Springs" show, Alan Wake also makes the world very believable, which helps to really set the mood. If you haven't played the game yet, and you aren't sitting on a giant vertical stick about gameplay, then you should really check out this game!

Posted: July 20, 2013
												Alan Wake is one of my all time favorite games.  This thriller is a step up from Quantic Dreams and their games like Heavy Rain and Beyond: Two Souls in the sense of making an enjoyable story whilst keeping the video game experience intact.  The Goods:  The story is incredible with many twists and character development.  The gaming UI is minimalistic yet helpful, and you can turn it off and still enjoy the game (see my guide to know how.)  The variety of enemies keeps the game challenging.  The graphics look good for the time it was made, however the setting of most of the maps has a lot of taxing fog on your machine.  A dodge mechanic is very satisfying to get out of the way of a flying axe.  The Not-So-Goods:  The combat can be a bit repetitiive and overwhelming at times, with many taken ganging up on you.  The game has manuscript pages are taxing to collect and kill the narritive.  While the game has some Story DLC, it seems a bit like an extended universe to compensate for the short yet slow main story experience.I give this game a 7/10.  The story is incredible, the graphics are good yet taxing, and the AI are a bit lacking in terms of the swarm mechanic they seem to develop, yet the gameplay mechanics cancel it out.

Взять хотя бы Барри, друга главного героя или братьев Тора и Одина Андерсон, создателей группы The Old Gods of Asgard :)Сам  геймплей получился весьма "необычным", в хорошем смысле слова. Удались многочисленные пейзажи местной глубинки.Я не припомню другой игры, где есть такой сюжет и атмосфера.Оценка: 9.5 из 10

content:

Alan Wake ReviewThird person atmospheric horror game with a major flaw.Alan Wake is a third person atmospheric game from Remedy Entertainment. I will start off by saying that although this game is good, it is certainly overrated by a long milestone. The game really looks like it's going to build up to something. It doesn't. That is the major flaw. The storyline doesn't make sense and the ending is disappointing and confusing. Yes, there is another game in the franchise, "Alan Wake's American Nightmare" that takes place a couple of years after the events of this game. But even that game doesn't explain what actually happened.The game is fun. The shooting is awesome and the mechanics feel really nice. Using a torch as a weapon felt awesome to me. The hidden traps and puddles of darkness were a nice touch. The enemies were never too difficult, but always a little bit challenging. At one point there is a shootout on a stage and Barry activates a bunch of fireworks and there's music playing and it's just fantastic. The characters in the game are pretty good, the voice acting, too. The driving in this game is appauling. This game and Just Cause 2 are the worst games for driving vehicles in my opinion.It's just that I don't know what Alan Wake tried to be. Did it try to be a horror game or an atmospheric game or a shooter game or an interactive movie? I mean, I just think Remedy decided "Let's make a horror game. But I want to make an action game too. content:
Posted: February 3, 2014
												Steven King gets his own video game!!!! No, not really, actually the story told by this game is a lot better than much of the recent releases by King, but he does get a reference or two in the game. All in all the setting is spot on, the fighting style can get a bit repetitive (shine light to remove immunity, shoot weapon), but they give you enough options to keep it interesting. Not to mention this game doesn't work well with bad accuracy. Your character is extremely squishy and can often get put into a stun lock when there are multiple enemies around, so some strategy is required for the pacing of which enemies you kill/stun and when. Range is your best friend in the game - second only to light, and while the game doesn't have any "cover" mechanics, if you are clever you can make your own. Ammo conservation is a major aspect of the game, but minimalists can still finish out an act with a stockpile of ammo. All in all, I'd say 9/10. Wake is a fantastic character, thrown into chaos; he goes with the flow with a sense of natural disbelief. If he weren't so driven to save his wife, he would go batshit crazy extremely early in the story. Even the semi-comic relief character Barry has a nice balance of annoyance and "this guy could really possibly be my best friend", all the while surprisingly making you hope he doesn't get killed the whole way through. With nods to various classic psycho-horror icons like "The Twilight Zone" in the games very own "Night Springs" show, Alan Wake also makes the world very believable, which helps to really set the mood. If you haven't played the game yet, and you aren't sitting on a giant vertical stick about gameplay, then you should really check out this game!

content:
Posted: July 18, 2014
												This is not a "survival horror." Not even a "terror" game. There are no scares, unless you are afraid of the dark, and there's no terror unless you hate Stephen King books.This is an action game with a supernatural component, an interesting (but simple) kill mechanic (use the flashlight to "light" the enemies, shoot them) and a bloody great told story, which jumps straight into the simple and fun Stephen King style and emerges with a really fun (and light) tale about dark beings, a missing wife and a forgotten writer.This game is made by the same guys who did Max Payne, and it is written in the same, dense, metaphor heavy style. If you liked Max's monologues in the original Max Paynes (1 and 2), you will love Alan Wake's adventure. There are a huge load of references to the original Max Payne, there are references to the nordic mythology (Together with one of the best moments in the game), there are a really good radio broadcast and a really interesting "Night Springs" TV show (both of them continuously referencing what's going on in the game)... all together band up to create a great atmosphere, and to make Bright Springs (The semi incomunicated US village in which the game takes place) a live place, with lot of interesting characters and really well written dialogues, without getting too complex or too boring to hear.The bad part is that gameplay wise the game is a bit repetitive: Light (let's calle them) dark zombie with flashlight, shoot, repeat. There are not too much different enemies but at least there are several different weapons to kill them, and, to be honest, the action feels right for the game: Just a good bang bang bang without too many options, but still, enjoyable.I can (and will) criticize the lack of variety in the game: Its like a game coming from 2004-2007 with its linear paths, its waves after waves of "dark zombies", a little bit of exploration and some "hold the fort" moments. Really fun, but nothing we haven't seen before. One could think that, with a mechanic as cool as being able to "play" with lights and shadows, the developers could have done something more interesting than just using as a mechanism to "aim" to the "dark zombies" and preventing the player to go all "rock 'n roll" with the big hordes.Still, the storytelling blends really well with the shooting sections: It does not distract the player when he is playing in the same way that the gameplay does not distract the player when the game is telling him part of the story, and this is something lot of developers should learn.In short, Alan Wake is an average-but-fun horror themed shooted with a really nicely told story. It does not do anything new, or innovative, but what it does, it does it quite right.So, yeah, thumbs up.

content:
Posted: December 21, 2013
												Engrossing mystery thriller with unfortunate gameplay weaknesses.Alan Wake is an immersive experience filled with mystery. Its greatest strength is definitely its plot. It captures its audience by presenting an interesting premise and questions that need answers, which ends up being the main driving force of the game. It did a fantastic job of keeping me interested throughout the game. The story is complemented by (mostly) well written dialogue and some (not all) well constructed characters. The issue I have with the plot is its ending, which contains no real closure or catharsis, which I imagine is due to a possible sequel. Another strength is the atmosphere. The dark tone of the game is achieved by a meticulous attention to lighting and a carefully picked soundtrack. It all blends together to form a dark engrossing mystery.Unfortunately the gameplay is its greatest weakness. It is thrilling and exciting at first, but quickly turns into a tedious routine that just stops you from exploring the storyline. The formula never changes: shoot the "taken" with light, then shoot them with weapons, rinse and repeat. The game does try to add some variety by adding elements of platforming, puzzles and even the illusion of exploration. Gameplay is in and of itself not bad. The problem with it is that the gameplay sections are too long. They're so long that whatever fun you had killing the taken dissapates very quickly. This is unfortunate, because I believe if those sections were made shorter, the game would feel a lot more immersive and connected.

content:
Posted: January 19
												Alright, I got a lot to say about this one because it really just baffles me.I don't understand how people forgive Alan Wake for all the glaring issues it has. I guess I can give it credit for trying to be unique, but underneath that... it tries to do a lot of things but fails to do them well. The only redeeming qualities for me are the visuals, sound and atmosphere. The facial animations really haven't aged well though; too often descending into uncanny valley territory.The combat is just frustrating and tedious. Most of the difficulty seems to be movement, positioning, timing, and to a lesser extent resource management based. It isn't really that hard, just strict when it comes to mistakes. Most importantly though, it just never feels fun, satisfying, or engaging.The light mechanic only serves to take control of the pace of battle away from the player, meaning most of the time you're just sitting around waiting for things to be vulnerable so you can shoot them. Everything has to be time consuming.Speaking of pace, almost every time enemies spawn the game goes into a slow-motion cutscene. This really takes away from the horror aspect of the game (if you can even call it a horror game, or a game at all) when you know nothing can ever really get the drop on you.And speaking of enemies, there are only about three or four of them. The way the game amps up the challenge is by just throwing larger amounts of them at you as you progress. There are no real boss fights either, unless you count utility vehicles and inanimate objects coming to life or "defend this position" segments.When you do have to run, Alan can only sprint for a measly few seconds before he has an asthma attack. There's also a dodge mechanic that's tied to your sprint key, which is unreliable and only works half of the time.Nothing about the story or characters intrigues me. I really don't see it as the massive step in video game narrative that everyone else does, it just takes itself too seriously and comes across as campy and pretentious. I'm sick of games trying to prove themeselves as a relevant artform when they don't need to, they always have been. Stop trying to make them like TV shows or movies, let them be their own thing.The plot is that you're a best-selling novel writer whose cliché horror story is becoming true, yet it takes the majority of the game to establish this point even though it's obvious from the very start. Also, your wife is missing, because of course she is.Alan narrates everything you do, and his voice is just... weird. Awkward. I don't think it's so much an issue with the voice acting as it is the audio equipment used, it really doesn't sound right.Characters constantly reference other, better horror stories and authors that remind me that I could be doing something better with my time.There are long segments where you just follow someone around while they repeatedly tell Alan he's crazy. When I'm playing these segments I just want to get to the game segments. When I'm playing the game segments I just want the level to be over. It's a cycle of constant boredom.The game is structured like an episodic miniseries. I really don't get why some games do this whole "Previously, on >insert show here<" rubbish, it's just really tacky to me. I don't even like it when TV shows do it so why the hell would it work in a game?The only thing to keep you going is the hope that there's some sort of payoff or revelation at the end.*Yawn*Oh yeah, and there's product placement. Yup. Buy Energizer! Their batteries last for a staggering five seconds!The irony is Alan Wake would probably make a better TV show, or hell, even a novel. But the way I see it there is just no sense slogging your way through this game for what it offers. It doesn't hold my attention at all. Then again, I'm of a small minority, and many people will just downvote me. So who knows, maybe everyone played a different game to me. ¯\_(ツ)_/¯I recommend watching someone else play it before buying.Good night, don't let the spooky shadow people bite.

content:
Posted: June 22, 2015
												This game is an underated gem in the survial horror genreYou play as Alan Wake, a writter looking for his missing wife in a sleepy woodland town thats being taken over by living darkness.  What this game does best is presentaion and atmosphere.  The levels are gorgeous during the day and spooky during the night and you'll find your self jumping at shadows and curising the sound of the wind.  The story is presented as if you were in a living book with Alan narrating the events and objectives as you play.  Things start to get really intresting when you begin finding pages to a manuscript that you have no memory writing and that describe things you have no way of know or even things that have yet to occur.  Top that off with amazing sound design and a kick♥♥♥♥♥soundtrack and i've never been so emersed in a game before.The games main short coming is combat.  To kill enemies you have to shine a flashlight on them until they become vunerable before shooting them. and thats it.  And theres only about 4 or 5 enemy types in the whole game so combat becomes samey real fast.  they do try to mix things up every now and then by throwing you into ambushes where you have to fend of multipule waves of enemies at a disadvatge or giving you a driving segmant here and there.  At least the controls are solid so combat doesn't feel frustrating.  There are also little hidden story elements and item cashes hidden through out the enviroments like radio boradcasts or episodes of a strange show similar to outer limits or twilight zone. this adds a bit of exploration to the leves and gives at least a little replay value.  This isn't a perfect game but its one that you really should play if you want a solid story and great atomsphere.

content:
Posted: May 28, 2015
												Alan Wake had a huge name before I even knew what it was about. Rumours and small spoils motivated me to play it for myself. On 1 May 2015 I finally set out on this adventure as a well known, cocky, used book writer who went on a retreat to Bright Falls in Washington, USA. It sets off on a slow pace and introduces you to all basic concepts and details.The main goal of Alan Wake was to create an immersive movie or story with little effort needed from the viewer, they achieved this with simple controls and an easy difficulty to play on. Do not be fooled and think that the entire story is all fun and games, at the end of each episode everything would get intense, hordes of taken would appear leaving you to fight or flee for your life.Categorised as a thriller I back the entire game, dwelling in silence with illuminating glare from the moon evolves slowly into a suspenseful walk with atmospheric music setting the tone of every scene. Even the classic jump scares are included, strolling through a home when suddenly a taken busts through the door charging you with al there is. Some were predictable and some were not, but balanced and not worn out.Physical gameplay felt unnatural and sloppy but to be fair it was a conversion form Xbox to PC. Minor glitches like getting stuck on something or jumping and getting stuck but no big problems.Graphics….. This was hard, reviewing in 2015 vs back in 2010 is quite a difference seeing that my GTX 760 made mincemeat of any graphical requirement it threw my way. Certain unpleasantness struck me in cinematics due to visible comers and edges, Alan’s Face his hands ect.BUTComparing to other titles released in 2010 it seems like the quality of visuals were up to standard, titles like Mass Effect 2, Just Cause 2, Assassin’s creed Brotherhood also had some of these characteristics that feels unpleasant to the eyes.This story was amazing and immersive…At first they make you compare yourself to Alan, at this stage you would feel all his pain. Then they drop an unravelling bomb on you where you start to hate our Hero, after a while you start agreeing again and feel his drive, anger, hatred and determination to finish his adventure.At the very end the unthinkable happens and they leave you on the biggest cliff-hanger ever created by mankind.They later on released special episodes 1 and 2 which continues the story after the story, these were not as good as the main story but also deserves your attention.  It does not really enlighten you about happenings after and if you can shut off your entire brain and only receive entertainment through playing games, I would implore you to do this as the FINAL did not give any closure and generated more hope than was needed.Unfortunately it seems that Alan Wake 2 will not make an appearance in the future, Quantum break releasing exclusively to Xbox one will receive this title. Producers and directors feel that it is not within the age or time to make a new Title to this extremely awesome piece of art and creative immersion.My next game would be Alan Wakes American Nightmare.Hit the review section up to see may say in a months’ time.FINAL VERDICT: ABSOLUTE YES, Add it to your rich-story category in your library.

content:
Posted: May 20, 2015
												Remedy Entertainment have a varied history on different platformer and a solid background of really polished, clean cut games with quirky/interesting takes on standard games. To me, Remedy Entertainment produce games that are like the interesting B-Side of the hit Pop record, and that's what Alan Wake is: Weirder and more interesting than the Triple A's, but with all the polish and production value you'd expect of one.HighlightsSuspenseful collectables and foreshadowing are layered around a very detailed world to produce some startling moments and encounters.* A newer angle on combat and some survival elements which make sense in the world of Alan Wake.* Quirky and interesting details to uncover in the world if you're inquisitive.* Very polished and few bugs.AnnoyancesAlan Wake is often called Stephen King: The Game, which is meant as a good thing. Interestingly though, it suffers from the same problems as Stephen King novels and movie adaptations; almost silly story elements and inexplicable character motivations. Otherwise, on the whole, it's polished enough that it never lets you down in any one area.* Easier than similar games and has a real lack of challenge.* Often no variety of enemies and repetitive combat.RecommendationsGameplay comes in at a strong 11-14 hours play time and while it doesn't have much re-playability, it's a collector/achievement hunters dream. It's available on Steam at between £22.99/$29.99 and £29.99/$39.99 which, for a 4 year+ old game is simply overpriced. Fortunately it goes on sale very often for -80% and even comes up in Indie Bundles from time to time.* The DLC is a waste of time. Instead, you can find the Developer Commentaries on YouTube here

content:
Posted: May 25, 2015
												Great action adventure with a fantastic story! The story alone is what kept me playing for 15 hours. The visuals and audio were beautiful, and the presentation of the content in a movie-like fashion was brilliant and fit the game perfectly. The NPCs in the game are VERY well done and helped lighten the mood in a dark game. Not to mention, I don't think I ever heard a repeated phrase by a character and I loved that about this game. The actual game play however was very poorly done for my taste. The fights were repetitive, predictable, intrusive, and unnecessary. Every 15 steps the game would interrupt my progression with a slow-motion introduction of a "new" set of enemies, and all I could think was "just let me play the game". It made enemies too familiar which took away any of the horror feel that they were supposed to bring to the game.There were a few pieces of actual game play that were fantastic and stood out from the rest in my eyes. The battle on the stage at the farm was the most enjoyable out of all of the combat scenes in the game. The music and the rock-and-roll stage scene made me feel like a boss killing all of the Taken, and having Barry there to cheer me on made it feel like I was fighting with a friend. Although not every combat scene can feel that epic, having more scenarios like this would have made the game play much more enjoyable. Even just changing up the music for other fights would have helped add variety.While I did not enjoy the combat, every other aspect of the game greatly helped it redeem itself. content:
Posted: November 25, 2013
												The vast and beautiful scenery in Alan Wake often gives the impression that the game is bigger than it is. I was, therefore, unsurprised to learn that the game was originally envisioned as being more of a free-roaming RPG before the limitations of the Xbox turned it into a a more liner 'on-rails' effort. And it shows. The landscape begs to be explored, but as soon as you travel any distance off the predetermined track you come to a cliff face or edge, and you start to feel a bit penned-in.The driving sections offer more of a sense of freedom, but even then you've got to stick to the road if you want to advance the plot.The story itself is interesting, and wears its Twilight Zone/Stephen King inspirations on its sleeve, but it has trouble captivating because from the very start you don't know what's real and what's a dream, which makes the threat feel too ethereal rather than something solid that can hurt you (even though it obviously can). You find yourself constantly wondering, 'is this bit a dream or real?', 'am I alive or dead?', 'do I really care?'.The atmosphere is the game's strongest point, and makes you wonder why more horror/suspense games don't do it better (I'm looking at you, Resident Evil series). The use of the flashlight is original, and the combat well executed, although it does suffer from being a tad repetitive by the game's end.It's a shame so much of the game is set at night (something necessary to the plot), because the graphics are showcased much better in the daylight scenes, and I'd have quite happily spent hours roaming around the hills and valleys of Bright Falls if given the opportunity.

content:
Posted: September 23, 2016
												With mounting pressure from his publishers and fans, a best-selling author suffering from writers block escapes with his wife to the small town of Bright Falls, Washington in search of peace and solitude. Instead, he is pulled into a twisted and dark nightmare when his wife mysteriously disappears. As the story plays out he finds himself battling himself as much as he is the dark enemies who appear around him, and the question never goes away: is it reality or is Alan Wake loosing his mind?PROS: The story is immersive, well written and excellently narrated Cool TV show like episodes give it a unique feel Music/SFX/voicovers are generally well done, play into the atmosphere Neat light/dark action combat idea Well developed town/characters (feels like out of a novel) Some decent logic puzzles scattered aboutCONS: Story drags a bit too long, gets out-of-hand Combat becomes too much of a focus later on (jumps between story, action piece, story, etc.) Control is a bit limiting/loose Lose weapons, items in between some sections of story Sometimes vague waypointsOverall, if the game is on sale I would highly recommend it. $30 (as it is when I write this) is a bit too much for a 6 year old game. That being said, it's generally a fun ride worth taking.

content:
Posted: June 22, 2015
												This game is an underated gem in the survial horror genreYou play as Alan Wake, a writter looking for his missing wife in a sleepy woodland town thats being taken over by living darkness.  What this game does best is presentaion and atmosphere.  The levels are gorgeous during the day and spooky during the night and you'll find your self jumping at shadows and curising the sound of the wind.  The story is presented as if you were in a living book with Alan narrating the events and objectives as you play.  Things start to get really intresting when you begin finding pages to a manuscript that you have no memory writing and that describe things you have no way of know or even things that have yet to occur.  Top that off with amazing sound design and a kick♥♥♥♥♥soundtrack and i've never been so emersed in a game before.The games main short coming is combat.  To kill enemies you have to shine a flashlight on them until they become vunerable before shooting them. and thats it.  And theres only about 4 or 5 enemy types in the whole game so combat becomes samey real fast.  they do try to mix things up every now and then by throwing you into ambushes where you have to fend of multipule waves of enemies at a disadvatge or giving you a driving segmant here and there.  At least the controls are solid so combat doesn't feel frustrating.  There are also little hidden story elements and item cashes hidden through out the enviroments like radio boradcasts or episodes of a strange show similar to outer limits or twilight zone. this adds a bit of exploration to the leves and gives at least a little replay value.  This isn't a perfect game but its one that you really should play if you want a solid story and great atomsphere.

content:
Posted: December 2, 2014
												Alan Wake is another stunning example of a stylish cinematic (and yet rich in gameplay) narrative experience that has become a trademark of Remedy Entertainment. Following the story of a writer who may or may not have found himself inside a horror novel he has been writing, this game is a delightfully postmodern journey that constantly makes the player doubt his perception, and the reality of time/space. What is true, what is but a dream, is the protagonist a "real" man or a character - but wait, isn't he the character of a game that you're playing? Drawing heavily on the style and works of Stephen King and David Lynch, Alan Wake leads you through a dangerous track of uncertainty, and through that achieves genuine tension. It may not be a very scary "horror game", but it definitely is filled with anxiety.Another highlight of Alan Wake is its unique multi-layered narrative - one that can only be found in the art of interactive media. The plot unfolds simultaneously through a variety of sources: the actual story experience, pages of an in-game novel that the player collects, occasional radio broadcasts, the timely use of licensed and original music, episodes of an in-game TV series... *and* the TV series that the game pretends to be with its episodic format! It's clever, it's ever dynamic and it is also a smart instrument of manipulating our fears. Every now and then the games "spoils" an event to come  - for example, by revealing an attack on the protagonist with the next page of a novel - yet it deliberately omits the circumstances, the "where" and "when", thus driving the player to assume that the said event might happen anywhere and at any time during the episode.With Alan Wake, Remedy Entertainment also re-establishes itself as one of the leaders in video game art direction. While it's simple to say the game is a beautiful one - and remains so even even now, at the dawn on the new console generation - it is first and foremost *effective* in employing colors, character and location design and, naturally, light and shadows to affect the player emotionally. Like any good horror story, Alan Wake builds up tension not as much through confrontation with "scary stuff" as it does by visually dividing safe areas, small and well-lit, and the vast dark misty territory of the unknown dangers outside. The game encourages exploration through various collectibles, yet here exploration require courage.In the world of Alan Wake, every step is not taken lightly - and thus matters all the more. This game is an engaging experience with a complex story, fascinating characters (all the more fascinating because of how they might not be real), outstanding game design and a sense of dread that is sure to cling to you for days to come, making your heart skip a beat every time you find yourself on a dark street with only a faint light of street lamp in the distance.

content:
Posted: December 28, 2014
												Do you like Stephen King? Would you like him in a game? Would you like him to take aim?Alan Wake is not a scary story. It has jumps, and can manage being creepy at times, but is the kind of "safe" horror that King often manages. A spooky, evil presence chases him around a northwest town obviously inspired by Twin Peaks (the developers' previous series, Max Payne, had an outright parody of the series) while he uses a flashlight to banish the evil - and then generally shoot it.I'm honestly uncertain whether or not this game is intended to have its tongue in cheek, but it's very much self-referential b-movie horror, and in that aspect it actually works quite well. Enemies growl ridiculous one-liners pointing to their former humanity, evil machines menace you, spooky messages from TVs - if you're willing to roll with the odd half-serious flavor and take in all the goofy story chunks, it's solid for fans of the survival horror genre. Mouse aiming makes the game a lot less challenging than I think it was intended, though the difficulty flips when you're outnumbered, as Alan doesn't have a great way to deal with being rushed from three sides, and the camera can definitely work against you when that happens. The way it uses light to relieve and increase tension is actually pretty smart, though the gameplay itself remains simple and somewhat repetitive throughout.Overall, though, I rather liked it. The story kept me engaged, and the threat ramps up to delightfully farcical levels by the end. It ends on a cliffhanger that leads into American Nightmare, which is interesting and flawed in about equal measure, and the sequel it needs has never materialized out of the darkness. It does include the console DLC that provides more resolution, and though the content in the DLC chapters seems warmed over, it does take breaking the fourth wall to an clever level. Ultimately it's a good romp if you're looking for a 90s b-movie that involves shooting a lot of grumpy, gloomy, guses along the way.

content:
Posted: December 2, 2014
												Alan Wake is another stunning example of a stylish cinematic (and yet rich in gameplay) narrative experience that has become a trademark of Remedy Entertainment. Following the story of a writer who may or may not have found himself inside a horror novel he has been writing, this game is a delightfully postmodern journey that constantly makes the player doubt his perception, and the reality of time/space. What is true, what is but a dream, is the protagonist a "real" man or a character - but wait, isn't he the character of a game that you're playing? Drawing heavily on the style and works of Stephen King and David Lynch, Alan Wake leads you through a dangerous track of uncertainty, and through that achieves genuine tension. It may not be a very scary "horror game", but it definitely is filled with anxiety.Another highlight of Alan Wake is its unique multi-layered narrative - one that can only be found in the art of interactive media. The plot unfolds simultaneously through a variety of sources: the actual story experience, pages of an in-game novel that the player collects, occasional radio broadcasts, the timely use of licensed and original music, episodes of an in-game TV series... *and* the TV series that the game pretends to be with its episodic format! It's clever, it's ever dynamic and it is also a smart instrument of manipulating our fears. Every now and then the games "spoils" an event to come  - for example, by revealing an attack on the protagonist with the next page of a novel - yet it deliberately omits the circumstances, the "where" and "when", thus driving the player to assume that the said event might happen anywhere and at any time during the episode.With Alan Wake, Remedy Entertainment also re-establishes itself as one of the leaders in video game art direction. While it's simple to say the game is a beautiful one - and remains so even even now, at the dawn on the new console generation - it is first and foremost *effective* in employing colors, character and location design and, naturally, light and shadows to affect the player emotionally. Like any good horror story, Alan Wake builds up tension not as much through confrontation with "scary stuff" as it does by visually dividing safe areas, small and well-lit, and the vast dark misty territory of the unknown dangers outside. The game encourages exploration through various collectibles, yet here exploration require courage.In the world of Alan Wake, every step is not taken lightly - and thus matters all the more. This game is an engaging experience with a complex story, fascinating characters (all the more fascinating because of how they might not be real), outstanding game design and a sense of dread that is sure to cling to you for days to come, making your heart skip a beat every time you find yourself on a dark street with only a faint light of street lamp in the distance.
