content:
Posted: December 21, 2012
												Despite the controls, which seems to be a source of anguish in just about every survival horror game, Alan Wake is a solid game guaranteed to keep you playing 'one more checkpoint' or 'one more chapter'. I started it yesterday and played it the whole day (with my shutters closed of course) and it hasn't bored me yet. The story is gripping and the characters are well-defined, even though the facial animation is so sloppy everyone seems to be suffering from a stroke all the time. And even though Wake is a geeky writer, it's extremely irritating to see him get winded, slowing to the speed of an octogenarian and gasping for breath every two seconds, even with crazy axe murderers chasing after him. As always, with any computer game in the history of the world, driving is horribly implemented (steering with the WASD keys, in this day and age? Seriously?!), and the strangely skewed third-person perspective is a bit uncomfortable for first-person aficionados like me, but I suppose that's part of the survival horror genre.I'm not gonna review graphics and stuff, because seriously, who gives a♥♥♥♥♥♥as long as the game is good? (They're lovely though)Still, those little things aside, if you like survival horror, this is a must-buy, and even if you're just indifferent to the genre, like me, it's still a worthwhile purchase - but wait 'til it's on sale again.

												Игра с отличным закрученным сюжетом. Всем советую поиграть!Сюжет игры повествует о приключениях писателя Алана Уэйка, автора бестселлеров в жанре «триллера», оказавшегося в городе Брайт-Фоллс, штата Вашингтон, где оживают персонажи и события его произведений. Пытаясь разобраться в происходящем и выяснить, что случилось с его женой, Алан узнаёт много неожиданного о маленьком городке — раньше здесь жил писатель Томас Зэйн. Его жена погибла, утонув при странных обстоятельствах в озере, рядом с которым они жили, хотя она и была прекрасной пловчихой. Зэйн, ныряющий на дно озера, в один прекрасный день обнаруживает там некую плывущую чёрную массу, с которой заключает сделку. Сделка состояла в том, что Зэйн пишет рассказ, и высвобождает Тёмную Сущность со дна озера. Она же в свою очередь воскрешает его жену — Барбару Джаггер.Барбара ожила, но это была лишь человеческая оболочка, заполненная Тёмной Сущностью. Томас осознаёт свою ошибку и вырезает Барбаре сердце, пытаясь уничтожить освобождённое им зло. Но это не останавливает Тёмную Сущность, Барбара по прежнему жива, и тогда он уходит вместе с ней под воду, но так и не достигает дна. А остров с домом исчезли, оставив жителей с новостью об ожившем вулкане под озером в 70-е. Призванный пером Алана, он приходит к нему на помощь и на краткий миг ослабляет Тёмную Сущность. Воспользовавшись этим, Уэйк в ужасе убегает из домика на острове, разбивается на машине, но выживает. Теперь ему придётся пройти сквозь океан ужаса и безумия, выжигая себе путь фонариком и встречая злобных тварей, от захваченного Тёмной Сущностью охотника и сошедших с ума федералов до завораживающего сердце торнадо.Кому лень это читать: http://ru.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alan_Wake#.D0.A1.D1.8E.D0.B6.D0.B5.D1.82

content:
Posted: October 18, 2013
												A thriller action adventure that plays with light and darkness. You take the role of Alan Wake, a writer, who goes on a vacation with his wife. Too bad their cottage (or the lake around it) is haunted and the darkness takes his wife hostage. Alan hits his head and is confused, alarmed and out-right horrified to find himself attacked by shadowy but unearthly shapes of townsfolk, friends and enemies alike. To survive he has to use light and gunmanship.Basically Alan meets a number of horrors along the way and beats most of them with elaborate use of light, guns and fast feet. Story advances smoothly along six chapters, each of which brings new kinds of enemies, tools and of course lore and insight into the destiny of Alan.After enjoying the story once you can play it through on a higher difficulty level, dubbed Nightmare, with stronger enemies and due to that scarcer resources. There are also two bonus chapters that are situated after the main story. The whole game takes anything from 15 to 25 hours to play through, more if you play it through with the higher difficulty level and even more if you go looking for all the extra stuff that gives you achievements. The main attraction however, at least to me, was the story that is enhanced by the immersion provided by believable body language and good voice acting.Get it for full price and you probably won't regret it anyway, but the game is frequently on a high discount that gets you a nice thrilling story with a price of a large soda.

content:
Posted: September 15, 2014
												I played through Alan Wake a year or so ago based on the recommendations of some friends. It turned out to be a fantastic survival horror type game that really centers on the story. If you’ve played the Max Payne games you’ll have a good idea of how the game story I presented. It’s almost like an interactive movie, making the first playthrough great, but might cut down the replay value (because you already know what happens).Spoilers aheadYou play the title character Alan Wake, a horror writer visiting a small town with his wife to get some rest & relaxation. After you reach your cabin in the woods, strange things start happening. Your wife disappears and the world is cast in darkness. Think Silent Hill, but instead of a “Hell World” it’s like night with swirling shadows all over. You eventually get pursued by law enforcement including a crazy FBI agent who seems to really hate you for some reason. All the while as you move through the world, you find glowing typewritten pages that are kind of like a book that you’re living (the pages are out of order though, so you don’t know what’s going to happen next). It turns out later that you’re living out a novel that you’ve forgotten writing and an evil force is trying to get you to write it in a certain way (so the evil force wins). Throughout the game there is voice over narration (by your character) that does a good job laying things out as well as describing the confusion that will probably be going through your mind. The game is played as a third person shooter where you will find various guns to use to defend yourself from the darkness. The enemies are mostly humans that have been “possessed” by the darkness and seem to have swirling shadows around them. These enemies are invincible until you destroy the shadows around them with your primary weapon, a flashlight. After the shadows are gone you can blast them with your regular guns. This is one of the only games I’ve played where the flare gun is the best weapon in the game. The flare gun totally destroys every enemy on screen with its bright flash. Pros:+Excellent story – practically an interactive movie.+Some scary parts when the enemies come after you in the dark.+Easy Steam achievements in this game :)+Cheap – the game was in a Humble Bundle for $1Cons:-Lower replay value due to it being so cinematic. Wait about a year before playing it again.-This is one of those games that can give you a headache when you play, not sure why. Probably because of the swirling shadows that are everywhere.-The game heated up my video card despite being on low settings. Overall I would recommend the game to anyone who enjoys horror, psychological thrillers, or just good stories. There is some very mild puzzle solving in the game but it’s mostly straightforward. If you get lost, just run towards the light! The sequel Alan Wake’s American Nightmare is a bit of a letdown afterwards. The same game mechanics apply but there is much less variety and less of a horror aspect. You can probably find the two games for cheap though since they seem to be on sale quite often for less than $5. The Steam edition includes 2 DLCs: The Signal, and The Writer. I skipped over them the first time I played the game but I’m trying them now.

content:
Posted: November 11, 2014
												What can I say about Alan Wake? Its an interesting game by the guys who did Max Payne, and it shows; Alan Wake is a story focused action thriller, much like Max Payne, but instead of being a neo-noir crime thriller set in New York City, Alan Wake is a supernatural thriller (though some people might call it horror, i'm a little hesitant to call it such, since it's not really scary) set in the fictional town of Bright Falls, Washington. Though it does have some shortcomings, ultimately, Alan Wake is a engrossing piece of fiction which does it's best to recapture the cinematic storytelling of Max Payne, and for the most part, it delivers.The game is visually impressive, with lighting being both stunning and a key part of the gameplay, and models being fairly well detailed. The shadowy particle effects when the enemies show up is neat, and overall the game exudes atmostphere. The musical score is decent, though utimately forgettable. Gameplay is probably the weakest aspect of Alan Wake, but it's still suprisingly solid. It has your standard set of third person controls, but what it adds is it's light mechanic. Enemies in the game cannot be killed unless they are weakened by light first. This can be from your torch (flashlight), a flare gun, or really any light source lying around. Enemies won't attack you under street lamps for instance, though often, to continue, you have to go out into the darkness and fight the enemies. there are some puzzley section in the game, but they aren't too difficult to figure out, but it's worth mentioning.Where Alan Wake really shines is in it's narrative, but moreso how it tells this narrative. While at first narrration by a Stephen King-esque character seems like it wouldn't be quite so interesting, the delivery is great. When things start to go wrong in Bright Falls, the atmosphere compliments the narratation. It works quite well, and in additon, splitting up the game into segmented chapters also adds to the Twin Peaks feel to the game. The story has plenty of twists and turns, and the dialogue is written well enough to keep you engaged. While the ending is somewhat dissapointing, Alan Wake's story (moreso it's storytelling) is excellent and will keep you engrossed until the end. If you like narrative driven games, or you like supernatural thrillers reminiscent of Stephen King or Twin Peaks, Alan Wake is definitely a recommendation.

												I feel like this game was marketed a bit wrong.At the time, this may have been a scary game, but certain mechanics and its writing were not original or top notch. Some reviewers noted how unique the light mechanic used in game was: you have to shine your light on enemies for a limited time before they can be taken down. However a similar mechanic was used nearly a decade earlier in Luigi's mansion (and there were probably games before and after that with similar mechanics as well, if we consider this a formula of "weaken with X in order to finish of with Y").Well aside from mechanics, the writing was highly praised. The writing in this game is functional, but it's nothing to write home about. These days it is much more common for a game's writing to blow people away (Telltale's Walking Dead comes to mind) but, there were games before Alan Wake (2010 on consoles, 2012 on PC) that had terrific writing. Planescape Torment, Fallout 2, Grim Fandango, Xenogear, System Shock 2, I don't think I could go on all day, but my point is clear: great video game writing existed before Alan Wake. More importantly, great synthesis of writing and gameplay existed before Alan Wake, and it is notably missing here. There are the usual suspects apparent: some cut scenes that offer little exposition and only serve to take control away from the player, some (probably most) of the characters are flat and cliche, some of the dialouge is lacking. However none of this is a huge offense, we are all just looking at it the wrong way.Alan Wake is largely a popcorn "horror" game. So, the writing has to be looked at through a different lens. The Sound and Fury is a terrific novel, as is Catch 22, but they are different kinds of novels trying to do different things in very different ways. So, Alan Wake is neither Faulkner or Heller. For better or worse, Alan Wake is a love letter to Stephen King, mostly. There are some heavy nods to the genius that is Rod Serling (of Twilight Zone fame) as well as Lynch (Twin Peaks). And these nods to the greats show in the lore, setting, and (still pretty cliche) characters. What that means for this game is, it is enjoyable. The writing is not some literary beast, chewing up the conventions of writing and spraying corrosive ideologies all over the human intellect. Alan Wake is simply a great blockbuster horror flick that you can play.After bleeding out all the things that didn't work, lets quickly look at what does. The use of missing pages from a manuscript do evolve into something better later, and it feels organic, which something everyone should appreciate in a good game. Where the main game is filling a general niche in the video game market, the 2 special episodes that serve as the games epilogue serve a much better purpose. I would have probably paid full price (or just 50% off, because this is Steam) for the 2 special episodes alone; these episodes show the mindbending game I was expecting when I thouht of a writer facing his writings in a game.There are some thrilling moments, nice camerawork, and overall smooth experience.There are some thrilling moments, nice camerawork, and overall smooth experience. Ambience and enjoyable writing match up nicely to make this solid game. Give it a try when the price is right for you, and I'm sure there is some aspect you will enjoy.

 Alan Wake Review I bought the Alan Wake Complete pack somewhere around 2011 and 2012, after seeing it at the G4 E3 broadcast and on X-Play, both now extinct. I wanted it so bad, but after seeing it was only for the XBOX, I forgot about it after a while. When I first joined Steam in 2010*, I wanted to buy a game to get full Steam features. After about a year, Sam & Max Seasons 1-3 were on sale, so I bought them. But in the process I saw Alan Wake, which at the moment hadn't sparked any memory of it. For around a year I waited to buy it, and when I saw it was on sale along with Alan Wake's American Nightmare, I had to buy it. Since then it has become and stayed my favorite game of all time, and that's saying something since I've played somewhere around 300-400 games, probably more. I'm going to keep this as un-biased as possible though. There may be spoilers. Alan Wake   Gameplay and StoryAs the story goes, Alan is a famous published author, writer of the Alex Casey novels, who has a severe case of writers block. Alan's wife, Alice Wake, takes Alan on a vacation to Bright Falls, a small town in the Pacific Northwest. Alan and his wife arrive at their lakeside cabin after Alan meets some locals at the Oh-Deer Diner, a cozy small town diner. Alan turns the power on for his wife, who is achluophobic, or has a fear of the dark. Alice calls Alan up to their room, and tells him to check the surprise she left in the study. When Alan opens the door, he finds his typewriter, and that his wife intended for him to come on this trip to get rid of his writers block. Alan get's very angry, and storms out of the cabin. This is where the game's story really starts. The power in the cabin turned off, and Alice screams. Alan yells her name hoping for a reply, and as he walks through the cabin, he finds the door to the dock open, and Alice drowning in the water of Mirror Lake. The game is played in a third-person view behind Alan. Alan narrates the game, also. There is a small selection of weapons, which consist of a  Colt Python ,  Orion Flare Gun ,  A Over & Under Shotgun ,  Winchester Model 1300 Defender* ,  Remington Model Seven CDL*  , and a  Model 7290 Flashbang Grenade* . The flashbang is sort of like an incinerating bomb to the enemies, called The Taken, which are composed of darkness. Usually you have to shine a flashlight on them to tear away the darkness, then shoot them. But with the flashbang, and the Flare Gun, you can insta-kill them. There are other items such as batteries, flashlights, and flares, which hold the Taken back a certain distance. Sadly, this game has no other features besides it's linear story mode and achievements. There is another Alan Wake game, Alan Wake's American Nightmare, but it has almost nothing to do with the story and is more of a shooter than a thriller. Remedy Entertainment stated that they have plans for an Alan Wake sequel, but Alan Wake wasn't financally succesful enough to start now, and they are going to finish their upcoming game, Quantum Break, first. I give this game a  9.5 out of 10  because of the ending, which was fine to an extent. I would recommend this to fiction writers and avid book readers alike.Thanks for reading this review,Def* I lost my other account when I forgot the password and had to make this one, hence the difference between dates on my account of when I made my account. In game the weapons are called Revolver instead of Python, Flare Gun instead of Orion Flare Gun, Shotgun instead of Over & Under Shotgun, Pump-Action Shotgun instead of Winchester Model 1300 Defender, Hunting Rifle instead of Remington Model Seven CDL, and Flashbang instead of Model 7290 Flashbang Grenade. 												I wanted to play this game for a long while but was afraid to spend $30 on it so I waited for it to go on sale. After playing all the way through the game I realized that this game is worth every penny and more of the regular price! It is one of the best games I have played in a long time. It unfolds like no other game I      have ever played and it is a thing of beauty.~The environment is beautiful and often terrifying ~The characters are great! They are funny, scary, emotional, believable and relevant! You really begin to care abot them.~The soundtrack is AMAZING! It could not be any better for this game.~The voice acting is top notch~The controls scheme is very unique and very fun once you get the hang out it.~It feels like true survival. You constantly feel like it is a fight for your life that you are losing.~Exploration is encouraged and often rewarding.~Night Springs, television, and the radio!... okay I could keep going with the pros all day, so let's get to the cons...Cons~The fight sequences are fun, but still become tedious after a while due to their abundance.~They are few and far between, but few parts of the game become trial and error, which can become frusterating fast.~The game is often creepy, but not truely scary. Unless you are afraid of the dark that is.VerdictThis is an amazing game. It has an amazing story, amazing character, an amazing soundrack; pretty much everything about this game is amazing. It feels like true survival and it encourages exploring. There is so much that is good about this game it is hard to touch on it all, but there are few things that hold this game from being perfect. The fights are repetative and can become annoying after a while. Some parts focused on purely surviving can be more trial and error. The game us not truely scary, but that is not a true hinderance. Overall it is one of the best games I have played in a long time.--Rating--    9/10

content:
Posted: November 7, 2016
												I tried.  I honest-to-God, really, REALLY tried to like this game, twice, but I can't.  I just can't.  Everywhere I see, this game has nothing but positive reviews, and I'm honestly wondering if Steam somehow pranked me into giving me a version from an alternate reality in which the game was bad.Alan Wake is a supernatural-themed game from the makers of Max Payne, dealing with the subject of dreams and darkness.  It tells the story of a writer named Alan Wake (get it?  A. Wake?  GET IT?!?), who suffers from writer's block so he goes on vacation with his wife to try and find some peace, but it turns out it's all just an excuse for her to try to give him some inspiration.  His wife, who suffers from fear of darkness, and apparently lives in a world where therapy doesn't exist, gets kidnapped by an unseen force and Alan wakes (tee hee) missing a week and finding the line between reality and fiction blurred, as he's suddenly haunted by people who are vulnerable to light and finds scattered pages he doesn't remember having written literally laying out the plot of the game for him.Now, I realize I made the game sound far more interesting than it actually is.  The game itself is REALLY dull, and it suffers from a personality disorder.  It's not sure if it wants to be a graphic adventure, a shooter, a survival horror or an interactive movie.  And instead of focusing on a genre and developing it, it half-asses all of them.  The graphic adventure part is slow and cumbersome, because Alan handles like molasses, with nary a puzzle in sight.  The shooter part is annoying because the only way to defeat enemies is by shining a flashlight on them to turn them vulnerable before shooting them.  You'll recognize this as "shooting, only slightly more annoying".  There's nothing clever about this mechanic, and you'd get the same result by having guns with smaller magazines, so you'd have to see the reloading animation more often.  Also, sometimes you're forced to run from enemies, but either Alan suffers from asthma or he's a wimp, because he runs for a couple of seconds and he already can't take it anymore.  Hell, *I* suffer from ashtma, and I can run longer without getting tired.The survival horror part is dead because this game's "horror" depends exclusively on jump scares, and we should all stop pretending surprise is the same as terror.  Also, children and Alan's wife believe darkness is scary, but other people don't.  At least not when the game botches is so early by showing all its cards right from the beginning.  And then there's the interactive movie part.  I tried to play this game close at launch and now, and I don't remember having ever be impressed by its ridiculous facial animations, so I don't think it's a problem of holding up.  They were always blow-up-doll-like laughable.  And technology is not the problem, the Playstation 2 could easily handle facial expressions much better.  But the real problem are the story, which is full of cliches, and the characters, who range from "meh" to unlikable.  Specially the main character, whose story arc seems to actually be going from one to the other, in that order.  This has nothing, though, on the fact that the plot is constantly spoiled literally minutes before it happens because of those manuscript pages.  Who thought that was anything even close to a good idea?I'm leaving the game now, for good.  If memory serves right, it will be at pretty much the same point I left it the first time I tried to play it.  Maybe it gets better later, but when a game can't ever pique my interest after more than an hour of playtime, I call it a lost cause.  I play games for instant entertainment, I have real life for when I want to slog through boredom to get to the good stuff.  According to other reviews, gameplay never changes, so I'm confident that I'm making the right decision.  I honestly don't get it.  Is everyone liking this game ironically?  Will I ever make someone's life so miserable that they'll go back in time to make this game just to annoy me?  I mean, I understand why people like other games I don't like, but this one is legitimately puzzling me, and probably not the way the developers intended.

Posted: March 13, 2014
												Alan Wake is a story-driven phychological thriller with one of the best plot in the genre. You play as Alan Wake, a burnt out writer who visits the small town of Bright Falls with his wife, Alice, for inspiration for his upcoming book called 'The Departure'. After the first night in Bright Falls, Alice is gone missing under mysterious circumstances, and Alan suddenly finds himself in the story of his unfinished horror novel. In order to save his wife, Alan needs to finish the story and find out of the dark secret of Bright Falls.The game is divided into 6 base episodes and 2 extra episodes, each starting with a short recap of the events of the previous one (except for the first episode of course.)During the span of the episodes, the story slowly unfolds, and the pieces of puzzle come together to form an outstanding plot.So, is Alan Wake worth playing? Yes, it is. Definitely but only for the story.Gameplay wise sadly it's one of the laziest work I've ever seen, there's zero effort in building tension past episode 2. All you get is cheap jump scares and massive hordes of enemies.And after a while you realize that the game only brings frustration and makes you angry, yet the plot is so good you will keep going just to get to the end of the story.PROS:- Graphics look pretty neat, especially the lighting and the landscapes.- The story! I can't emphasize this enough, the biggest value of the game is the story!- The lore and characters. The developers put a lot of details into the world of Alan Wake!- Radio shows, manuscripts further extends the knowledge of the plot.- Night Springs. An in-game TV show that's inspired by Twilight Zone.CONS:- Gameplay is a trainwreck!- Massive hordes of enemies ruin the tension and atmosphere. It also causes frustration and anger.- Alan Wake's stamina is lower than a 80 year grandpa who's been shot with a tranquilizer. Translation: he can't more than 10-15meters without being completely exhausted. I know the game is supposed to be a survival game, but come on!- The gameplay gets extremely repetitive and predictable at a certain point: see a barrel, or a broken down car? 99% they are poltergeist objects and will jump on you. See a generator that you need to restart? You will get swarmed by enemies as soon as you go near it.- Despite having collectibles and hidden items, the game does NOT like you wandering off the linear passage and often punishes you with waves of enemies.TLDR: Play Alan Wake for the story!

Posted: December 1, 2013
												The light fantastic (almost)Credit is due Remedy for making ALAN WAKE a story-driven game. It’s a partial success, though not a complete one. They have entirely eschewed the typical RPG tropes of dialogue trees and progression choices in favour of a linear, non-interactive structure. The story is played out in a series of cut-scenes and simple A to B tasks. Basically you just have to battle your way from one place to the next. There’s certainly a place for this type of game, and when it’s done well (á la Half-Life 2) it can be very rewarding. Unlike Half-Life 2, however, ALAN WAKE doesn’t quite pull it off. Firstly, there isn’t enough humour. There’s some but it would have benefited from more. And the story isn’t exactly original. But the main problem for me was the combat. I hated the way control is wrenched away from the player every time enemies approach. I get why they did it (there’s no other way of knowing they’re coming, apart from some audible warnings) but I often found myself disoriented when the camera had finished sweeping around and control had retuned. Several times the sweep lasted so long that by the time I had control again the enemies were right on me and it was impossible to avoid taking a hit. Frustrating to say the least. On the plus side the environments look very good and it’s quite atmospheric (although not as creepy as I would have liked – Silent Hill still sets the bar for that). One other thing worth noting is that I found the special episode, The Writer, to be better than what had gone before. It’s even more atmospheric and far more inventive. Overall this is a good game if not an outstanding one.3/5

The worst of all are the driving sequences where all hell breaks loose.As for the game...This has to be the most realistic game I've ever played: Alan can't run, Alan can't jump, Alan can't aim, Alan doesn't plan ahead and keeps losing his weapons, Alan is booring, Alan keeps getting into trouble.Then there's the other side, the unrealistic side where the game keeps spawning enemies just for dificulty sake, where you are punished for exploring, where AI is given an unfair advantage, where you only have the ONE path.All that make this game very boring and the "It's a horror genre game" excuse doesn't cut it.I was ready to ditch this game by hour 3 but after so many "It get's better later on" comments, I've completed the game and I can say: THAT'S A COMPLETE LIE! The game only get's more frustrating as it progresses.Try the demo to see if you like it first, but I can't recommen this game. It's just too frustrating, especially coming from Rockstar.

												Just completed the Alan Wake experience. I say experience because it was an imersion in movie, novel and game.It places emphasis on the most important thing a lot of games these days are lacking: a good story. This story was told in a way that spared no expense in quality. From the atmosphere, to the sound track that includes well known artists, to the detail of graphics and textures. The importance of the way light and lighting was used in the graphics and story sets this game apart.It has well developed characters, stories within stories that aren't boring and epic, well directed cut scenes all set in a picturesque, haunting environment. I think the only thing that let it down was the marketing and publicity as if it had of been promoted more, I would have got to it sooner.

content:
Posted: November 4, 2015
												The game has absolutely stunning visuals, a very full and well developed atmosphere, and a story that I found to be truly enthralling, all accompanied by a solid narrative and interesting storytelling. So, all of this considered, why do I not recommend this game? While enjoying the atmosphere, trying to focus on the beautiful visuals, and contemplating the artfully crafted thriller-narrative being unravelled as I play, the last thing I want to do is be subjected to relentlessly spawning mobs of 3-5 of the same uninspired enemy every 10 seconds. Especially when each individual enemy in these  mobs takes 5+ seconds of shining a boosted flashlight on him and a minimum of 3 shots from a six shot revolver to be defeated, all while the other guys batter you with axes.I am not wanting to take away from the fact that the combat was well inspired and tried to do something new, because it definitely did. You don't just blast away at whatever appears out of thin air until it falls lifeless: there is a method to the mayhem... but this doesn't change the fact that the combat is repetitive, time-consuming, clunky, and more a of a distraction than a benefit to an otherwise great game. Another viable alternative would have been the Mirror's Edge route: making it possible to avoid combat entirely. With some refinements to the dodge system and making it so you no longer run like a midget with one normal sized leg, you could actually run from that which terrifies you and this game would really feel a lot more like a thriller/horror game.Sadly, the combat was actually bad enough that I had to stop playing one episode from the end... even in light of all the great things it had going for it. Though I will definitely be finding a playthrough online to give me some closure on the story.

content:
Posted: June 3, 2014
												Alan Wake is less a horror game and more of a story experience. The horror aspects are all but lost unless you are playing on the hardest difficulty, which takes two or three playthroughs to unlock, and the difference is palpable. On anything but nightmare mode, a shadowy man will pop out on occasion and after going shine shine shine, glack glack glack, the threat is gone and you can continue with the story. On nightmare mode the game is completely different. Hordes of shadowy abominations of our reality will pour from the woods while you desperately sprint towards the next pinprick of light only to have it wink out as you near it. Then you pop a flare and continue the full tilt sprint to the next shining becon of hope, only for Wake to get tired and then get an axe in the back of his head.Nightmare mode seems to be the way the game was MEANT to be played, but you can't access it without 2 other plythroughs, which is simply asking too much. Personally I play through a game once and am done with it unless theres some crazy alternate endings that I HAVE to get, wich there aren't here. Which brings me to the story. Alan Wake's story is a cross between Stephen King and Twin Peaks, with a heavy dose of lovecraft mixed in. I will not spoil anything in this, but the story is truly the best aspect of this game. It keeps the player thinking about what will happen next and where this♥♥♥♥♥♥storm of nightmares will end up. In the end, Alan Wake is not a particularly scary game, unless played on the highest difficulty. The story and immersion are it's strong points, but one playthrough is probably enough, unless you are a completionist, then this game has plenty for you in the forms of thermoses scattered around the playing areas. This game is a definite 8/10, nothing♥♥♥♥♥♥your-pants amazing, but still enough that everyone should play it one time through.

content:
Posted: March 22, 2015
												Alan Wake is a truly underrated and sadly ignored game which did not receive the kind of attention it deserves. This game is not perfect, but it still does most everything right to the smallest detail, in the most original and creative of ways. First off, the atmosphere is absurdly engaging, realistic, absorbing, and scary. The lighting engine especially in this game is better than any game I've seen so far. Which makes sense, considering how essential the lighting mechanics are for this game. What people say is correct - it is literally like playing through/experiencing a Stephen King novel. It is wonderfully cinematographic, during gameplay and in the cutscenes. Plus the voice acting is top notch, perfect attention was given to sound details and animations, and the story is really well paced. The story and the game's atmosphere keeps you on your toes the entire time, with unpredictable plot progression and developments, and a twisting, deep, surprise-filled story.Speaking of tension, this is one of the few games that actually makes you address each battle scenario strategically (A few others being Bioshock, Borderlands, etc.). You are so scarce on ammo and flashlight batteries throughout most of the game, that you start to bug out when you are running out of ammo, and the enemies keep spawning anyway, as if they thought you were Rambo or something. You scour every area of the map looking for any bits of ammo you can find. Each enemy takes so much work to kill that it can easily get overwhelming and you can quickly use up your ammo.The game implements some pretty crafty platforming and environmental puzzles, particularly in the The Writer DLC. Albeit short, I greatly enjoyed that DLC  because it was just pure creativity, from beginning to end. I did not enjoy the The Signal DLC as much, but it was still good. That one felt too repetitive and eventually got quite frustrating, but it still had creative content and impressive technical feats.You get plenty of gametime out of this game - 11-14 hours for the main story alone. And then 1.5 hours for each of the DLC, and also however much time goes into finding all the hidden objects spread throughout the levels, if you are into that kind of thing.So in summary, with a fantastic, original, well-paced, complex, non-cliche and creative story, a very impressive game engine that looks absolutely gorgeous a LOT of the time (I took 175 screenshots in my single playthrough. :D), solid shooting mechanics, nice attention to detail, a consistently frightening and tense environment, and excellent level design, this is a game I would HIGHLY recommend, to anyone who feels they can handle a psychological horror game of this degree.

content:
Posted: May 18, 2015
												Being a game that begins with the letter "A", Alan Wake is constantly eluding my vision as I scroll up and down my Steam Library. Sometimes I forget I own it, and when I remember, I have to convince myself that I actually played it. When the memories all come back, Alan Wake slams me in the face and forces me to look down at that towering list of games it stands above, not only because it is alphabetically superior, but outwardly superior as well.The narrative is so tight, so well-woven that it breathes in and out, heaves spit in your face, and so humid you can taste the ripe Stephen King inspiration on the tip of your lower lip, unless your lower lip decides to fall open for the mind-blowing finale and your mouth becomes vulnerable to the sweet juiciness it leaves on your tongue. Seldom can games be described as such.However, I forget this fact. There it is, standing on a heap of otherwise sub-par games, escaping the "Top 10" lists I like to think up in my head, when it should be modeling at the forefront of story design for future games. The point is that it wasn't a wholly memorable experience. I really hate to admit this, considering how powerful a game it was in scope and atmosphere, but the game itself plays like a Stephen King novel: a single-dose experience that will likely be temporarily surpassed until it can come rushing back to your tongue. It's difficult that way. There's no dishonor in this; if anything, Alan Wake acts like a reality check, like a list of criteria all games must now meet before they can be truly commended for the features they present. Oftentimes I will come back and make sure I don't go overboard about loving a certain game until I pay my tithe to the king of all, if only a spiritual one: Alan Wake.Buy it on a sale. Don't promise yourself to replay it, because you won't, but it offers an array of emotions that can rarely be captured. You won't ever fully appreciate how great it is, but that's okay, because it's still going to give you an impression you will HATE to see another games attempt to imitate.

The best way to describe the game is a survival horror done int he way of an interactive short tv series with an overlying narrative like that of a visualized book. The gameplay is magnificent and controls are at times a bit extensive but easy to get used to. It's very environmentally interactive and nearly as realistic and logical as a game can get. This game is fun in terms of reading a good mystery novel, only you're in control and replace the need to read text, there are stunning visuals, haunting melodies, and the goal to help you, Alan wake, discover what is reality and what is fiction, if reality still even exists. Writers truly get lost in their work...

The combat, surprisingly for a third person game, is not set behind chest high walls in a whack-a-mole fashion. Instead you must run about with some rather clunky dodging skills and point a torch at things -then- fill them with bullets. The nature of the enemies presented makes them well suited to the genre but since bullets are nearly always in abundance their threat isnt all that great which diminishes their effects.While still entertaining to a degree, that its story really outranks its gameplay is a sign that it had a lot of thought and care put into it, the odd presentation in that the game is divided into chapters which each have an ending sequence quickly followed by a recap makes it seem it was written for a different medium - the tendency for each chapter to have a high tension ending followed by an unneeded stripping and debriefing to put the player into the next chapter is quite jarring.That said; the unconventional pre-warning of the story to the player is well thought out and - more importantly - well used. While the player may learn what will happen, its never said how or why or (in cases) when. By loosely leading the story like this it creates anticipation as well as a foggy conclusion which works just right, adding a slight overarching mystery affair.Also, as a protagonist, Alan is a pretty big♥♥♥♥♥♥ Not Nathan Drake cuntish, but still nearing that.

content:
Posted: May 18, 2015
												Being a game that begins with the letter "A", Alan Wake is constantly eluding my vision as I scroll up and down my Steam Library. Sometimes I forget I own it, and when I remember, I have to convince myself that I actually played it. When the memories all come back, Alan Wake slams me in the face and forces me to look down at that towering list of games it stands above, not only because it is alphabetically superior, but outwardly superior as well.The narrative is so tight, so well-woven that it breathes in and out, heaves spit in your face, and so humid you can taste the ripe Stephen King inspiration on the tip of your lower lip, unless your lower lip decides to fall open for the mind-blowing finale and your mouth becomes vulnerable to the sweet juiciness it leaves on your tongue. Seldom can games be described as such.However, I forget this fact. There it is, standing on a heap of otherwise sub-par games, escaping the "Top 10" lists I like to think up in my head, when it should be modeling at the forefront of story design for future games. The point is that it wasn't a wholly memorable experience. I really hate to admit this, considering how powerful a game it was in scope and atmosphere, but the game itself plays like a Stephen King novel: a single-dose experience that will likely be temporarily surpassed until it can come rushing back to your tongue. It's difficult that way. There's no dishonor in this; if anything, Alan Wake acts like a reality check, like a list of criteria all games must now meet before they can be truly commended for the features they present. Oftentimes I will come back and make sure I don't go overboard about loving a certain game until I pay my tithe to the king of all, if only a spiritual one: Alan Wake.Buy it on a sale. Don't promise yourself to replay it, because you won't, but it offers an array of emotions that can rarely be captured. You won't ever fully appreciate how great it is, but that's okay, because it's still going to give you an impression you will HATE to see another games attempt to imitate.

content:
Posted: September 13, 2012
												Note: This game is polarizing and I will give my best ability to not give an unbiased review.What this game does right is captivating the audience into playing more. The game is set in an episodic story arc, weird for a video game, but Alan Wake pulls it off. It is not like The Walking Dead Episodic series, but instead each chapter is broken into the episodic format. At the beginning of each episode (excluding episode one) is a recap of the previous episode. If you are like me and you continue to play through the game, then the recap is not really needed, but it does keep the tone of the game. At times these recaps are helpful when it comes to remembering the plot or just returning back to the game. At the end of each episode, the credits roll and a song is playing. Once you skip or let the credits roll, the game will send you to the next episode. The story overall is fantastic and the game’s writers knew what they wanted for the game. These writers are famous for writing the first two Max Payne games, so the majority of the story is told through Alan Wake, the protagonist, as the narrator. The story is about Alan Wake, a successful writer who suffers from writer’s block. He and his wife, Alice, go to Bright Falls, where they vacation to clear Alan’s mind. Then in their stay, Alice is pulled into the darkness and it is up to Alan to save her. Along the way Alan discovers manuscripts of his work in progress, Departure which tells a chilling story of events, and Alan realizes that whatever is on these pages will happen in the real world. This short summary of what is to come in Alan Wake. The gameplay is a story of its own. The basic mechanics of Alan Wake are to get from point A to point B with enemies and puzzles to get in the way. Fighting enemies in this game are not in the traditional sense. The theme of Alan Wake is Darkness, and the ironically named Bright Falls is being taken over by the Darkness. The Darkness consumes people and Alan Wake has to shine light from his flashlight on his enemies to clear the Darkness from them before he can shoot and kill them. Not only does Alan Wake fight, but he has a dodging mechanic to where he ducks and weaves from his enemies that either attack or throw tools at him. This feature, like Max Payne’s shoot dodge, is used a lot to avoid enemies. Now what this game does poorly is its character expression during cut scenes. The character development is awesome and the models are great, but when the characters speak, their lips and face are awkward enough to question the games programming, but it is not so bad that it takes away from the experience of the game. Another complaint is the PC port has a couple of glitches when I played, but Remedy remedied that (lol). Also the gameplay to a certain degree is a bit tedious. The running from point A to point B while doing rendered the same actions over and over is a little bit redundant at times, but there is enough variety in between these segments to make it not boring. Ultimately, the story is what saved Alan Wake from being a generic third person game to being a great experience overall. The story is what keeps you playing; the story is what makes you care for the characters; the story is what drives the gameplay home. You cannot go wrong with purchasing this game.  Scale:Story 10/10*Writing, Pacing, and Voice actingGameplay: 8/10*Fun, but redundant to a pointGraphics 9/10*Fantastic landscapes and models, but glitches in talking and walking.Replay value: 8/10*Great, like watching a movie, and there are collectables.Effort: 9/10*The Designers took 5 years to make this, but the glitches is what makes it a 9._____________________________________________________________________________________Overall: 9*Rating Scale is based on the average of the 5 main categories and round to the nearest number.Thank You for reading first effortful review. Please let me know how I did.

content:
Posted: May 15, 2016
												What is Alan Wake? Summed up: Luigi's Mansion meets Twin Peaks meets Deadly Premonition and with a small serving of early '90s slasher/action flick on the side.For some of the flaws and missteps it takes, Alan Wake is an enjoyable experience, especially for those with a penchant for creative writing. The titular character, Alan, acts as an avatar of sorts for writers and players and for those inclined, both. He takes a vacation in the sleepy town of Bright Falls, located somewhere in the state of Washington. It is here he finds out - rather harshly - that there are dark forces at work, and with it, unveiling a mystery that engulfs the town.Don't be fooled, however; this is not a traditional horror game. It has more in common with action-adventure games such as Uncharted and Alone in the Dark 2 than it does with more cerebral games like Silent Hill and Sanitarium. The game plays with a behind the shoulder perspective and your crosshair, so to speak, is provided by a flashlight. Even so, the game controls rather well and Alan's movements and responsive and crisp. There are a few parts where the rather solid movement can make jumping from one platform to the next a little cumbersome, but those are a minor gripe. As for the graphics, they do the job. Often times, you can notice artifacts or little quirks, such as questionable facial animations, but if Fallout 4 can get a free pass for that, so can Alan Wake.The game's biggest flaw (outside of icy driving controls) is the fact that you cannot explore the town of Bright Falls, as the game is incredibly linear in its direction. You cannot hang out at a local joint like you can in Deadly Premonition or talk to random strangers and get a feel for the town. The reason why I note this is that the characters and dialogue, and by extension writing, are all quite wonderful. All the characters are vibrants with their quirks and personalities. A no-nonsense sheriff, a trigger-happy agent, a disturbingly unfettered doctor, they all stand out vividly. The gameplay itself is nothing to write home about, but it keeps you on your toes and some might find it repetitive at times. But the scenery and massive levels are more than enough to keep you engaged.[On that note, getting the game with the DLC is highly recommended. You get two full-length episodes (~2 hours of gameplay) that continue the story straight from the ending. They are quite fantastic and switch up the formula nicely.]Oh, and the soundtrack? ♥♥♥♥ing incredible.Conclusion: Get the game when it's on sale, you won't regret it.8/10.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 15, 2015
												The reason i gave this game a thumbs up is because of the interesting story, It outweights the somewhat boring and repetitive gameplay.-----------------------------------------------Here is what i liked about the game:- Really interesting story- Overall unsettling atmosphere- Manuscripts you can pickup in the game (Basicly the story you're playing, but it's interesting to read)- Good graphics, not the best but good enough- A few intense momentsI really liked the story, one of the better i have heard in a long time in a video game. while it's not a completely scary horror game it's unsettling enough to creep you out from time to time. While i liked that you could pick up your manuscript pages, it also kind of revealed what would happen later in the game. While the forests sure looks beautiful with lots of details and textures that's good enough, you can't help but think "Not another ♥♥♥♥ing forest" later in the game. Ohterwise, the game gots graphics good enough to deliver. And there's a few key moments that was intense and really interesting i won't mention here for the sake of not spoiling it for anybody.-----------------------------------------------Now here is what i didn't like about the game:- Linear and repetitive gameplay- The same ghostmen over and over again (The variations is: Normal guys, Big guys and Fast guys)- It's pretty predictable to spot when you will get ambushedThe game pretty quickly becomes linear and repetitive since you have to follow a path in the game and kill the same ghostmen the same way over and over. There's a couple of ways to deal with them, but it quickly becomes the same and you quickly learn how to deal with certain types of enemies. also like i mentioned.. you will get tired of forests sooner or later. When you're through the first episode, you will probably already know when to expect company by your best friends, the ghostmen.-----------------------------------------------In the middle:- The ending- Coffee collectablesThe story itself was good, but the ending makes you think and i am still kind of lost. I still don't really know what the hell happened. (Maybe you'll get it) The coffee collectables... don't really know how i feel about them. They don't do anything and kind of feel out of place.The Verdict:All in all, a good game with an interesting and unsettling story, but i don't want to play it again because of the gameplay. The only reason to play it again would be to play Nightmare mode to get all the manuscript pages, yes there is some manuscript pages you can only get by playing on nightmare mode.. which means you have to play the game twice. Now i'm off to play the Alan Wake's American Nightmare game.

Posted: May 24, 2014
												If you play games for the game play mechanics, then you might like this title. Alan Wake is a third-person survival horror mystery. The main character is a writer, so he is portrayed as not very athletic. This translates into the feeling of slugish and unresponsive movement. Enemies must first be cleansed of darkness by shining a flashlight on them for varying amounts of time (3-10 seconds). I found this mechanic to be a bit frustrating later in the game. The flashlight also acts as the targeting reticule. There are 5 different guns available: revolver, double-barrel shotgun, pump-action shotgun, hunting rifle and the flare gun. The flare gun acts as a rocket launcher since all of the enemies are weak to light. There are also flashbangs and road flares. Ammo is somewhat scare, and there will be times when the player will be out of ammo if care isn't taken. There is no upgrade system in this game.If you play games for the storytelling, then you will probably like this title.  The main character and his wife go on vacation to a small pacific northwest town in an attempt to cure his writer's block. I found the characters to be mostly interesting. I also though that the dialog and voice acting were very good.The design of the world and the characters is very good in my opinion. The lighting is mostly dark, though. There are a few sections of the story that take place during the day, but most of it is during the night.I was annoyed by the frailty and sluggishness of the main character, and the fact that most of the game takes place at very low light levels. This obviously gave a sense of urgancy to everything, but this changed to annoyance for me towards the later parts of the story. I also foung the game to be more challenging than I would have expected on the lowest difficulty setting.Overall, I enjoyed my time with this title. Aside from the annoyances, I found the story to be well worth it.

content:
Posted: May 29, 2013
												A rather unique title, Alan Wake sets you in a richhorror environment which - contrary to its genre - takes the bold turn to tell you the story before it happens. The combat, surprisingly for a third person game, is not set behind chest high walls in a whack-a-mole fashion. Instead you must run about with some rather clunky dodging skills and point a torch at things -then- fill them with bullets. The nature of the enemies presented makes them well suited to the genre but since bullets are nearly always in abundance their threat isnt all that great which diminishes their effects.While still entertaining to a degree, that its story really outranks its gameplay is a sign that it had a lot of thought and care put into it, the odd presentation in that the game is divided into chapters which each have an ending sequence quickly followed by a recap makes it seem it was written for a different medium - the tendency for each chapter to have a high tension ending followed by an unneeded stripping and debriefing to put the player into the next chapter is quite jarring.That said; the unconventional pre-warning of the story to the player is well thought out and - more importantly - well used. While the player may learn what will happen, its never said how or why or (in cases) when. By loosely leading the story like this it creates anticipation as well as a foggy conclusion which works just right, adding a slight overarching mystery affair.Also, as a protagonist, Alan is a pretty big♥♥♥♥♥♥ Not Nathan Drake cuntish, but still nearing that.

												A real review.The missing tag for Alan Wake in it's discription is 'story driven'. Alan Wake is a story driven game. There are many good things about this game but it is the story that will compel you to finish it.The horror aspect is mixed into the gameplay and it works at the start as you nervously walk through a forest at night with the feeling you are being chased by axe weilding country folk. As the story progesses you will master the combat style of duelwielding a flash light and a gun to kill the 'darkness'. Once mastered you find yourself collecting heaps of ammo, flares, flashbangs etc, so much so that no matter what object the 'darkness' chooses to posses you will have more than enough to defend yourself and loosing some of that horror in the process.The gameplay is different than anything else i have played which straight away makes it fun. Visually, the world you are in is beautiful, dark, dangerous and mysterious. The sound is also very good. The game has a great atmosphere. But...The cutscenes and story are so so so much better than the level design and gameplay that you will reach a cutscene, learn more of this increasingly interesting and captivating story, you will be all excited to find out more when Alan somehow manages to fall back into a forest. A dark forest. You finally get to the next cutscene, awesome, more story but then Alan slips and falls into the forest. Cutscene, forest, cutscene, another ****ing forest. That is how i felt playing this game by the end. I was racing through the level to get to the next part in the story. The horror gameplay really takes a back seat maybe half way through the game.But the story is that good that you will want to keep playing. One last thing, there is one type of enemy that you come across , little spoiler...It is so annoying, runs super fast so you cant shine your flashlight on it until it attacks you. It runs all around so you dont know from which direction will it jump out of the darkness, sounds scary but it isn't. It takes so long to try attack you that you have to stand there for a few minutes waiting. It's frustrating. You will know this enemy as soon as you see him. If he takes too long to attck you just run to the next checkpoint and he will dissapear. Really stupid character.All in all, if you want an action game with non repetitve gameplay this game is NOT for you! If you want something different with a great story this game IS FOR YOU! I liked it accept for that one type of enemy, so stupid, shouldn't be in the game.

content:
Posted: June 19, 2016
												Imagine if Stephen King wrote a season of Twin Peaks.Alan Wake is a frustrated writer taking a break with his wife to the small, secluded town of Bright Falls. All is not as it seems as there is an undefinable evil hiding in the woods, stalking townspeople and turning them into crazed monsters known as "taken". When Alan's wife dissapears, he must venture into the woods to find her and piece together what happened using pages from a book he doesn't remember writing.Alan Wake is a tense, forboding horror game. The most notable feature is the "fight with light" mechanic, where the taken are invulnerable to regular weapons until you burn out their protective aura using your torch, flares and flashbangs, as well as stationary light sources. Combat is a close quarters affair, as your dodge mechanic lets you evade slashes by the skin of your teeth. There isn't really any boss fights but there are occasional poltergeists (inanimate objects infused with the darkness and act as missiles) as well as some great set pieces to add variety to the combat.Remedy's use of light and shadow in Alan Wake is outstanding, helping to create an incredible sense of dread. Seening a quick fog come screaming through the trees and catching glimpses of taken watching you from the distance is quite unsettling.The story is quite good, even if it does contrive reasons for Alan to be out in the woods every night. The game is divided up into six episodes (8 if you include the DLC), each with their own recap and credits making you very much feel like you're playing a t'v show, even if the lip-synching is pretty poor.All in all, Alan Wake is an excellant game. I wouldn't call it survival-horror as you're usually kept reasonably stocked up on ammo but more as psychological horror, as you are constantly asking yourself what's real and what's not. Alan Wake stays with your for a long time.

content:
Posted: March 13, 2016
												Let's start with the overall setting: the game's very atmospheric. The world is finely crafted and believable and makes the player want to go exploring it further. It's designed like a TV show, and it pays homage to Twin Peaks and other mystery/thriller shows. I also liked the tongue-in-cheek humour in the Twilight Zone parodies and TV talk shows. The characters are memorable and even likeable (except Alan himself IMHO). The characters have a pretty decent voice acting, but horrible lip-syncing. Their mouths are just unnatural and gave me the creeps (purposefully uncanny valley or just inability/laziness?).The gameplay is smooth and involves a heavy use of light, which adds to the atmosphere nicely. The shadows are impressive. Unfortunately the gameplay repeats itself and you start noticing some patterns. For example, you mostly run through linear paths, fighting enemies every 2 minutes. And at the end of the path there's a calm area and you always drop down into a lower platform, so that you can't go back where you came from. This is an arena, where you have to hold out for a certain time or fight a miniboss. Or your path is suddenly blocked off by some falling debris or something and you have to find another way around. You always see it coming and it gets really tiring after a while. This is my main gripe with the game; it's repetitive.The game starts slow and picks up the pace around midway through. It kind of keeps you interested throughout, just enough to not make you want to uninstall it before finishing it. But if you're not a patient player, this game might not be worth your while. In the end, you're not missing much. I'm recommending this game for its atmospheric qualities only, the rest is a bit unrewarding. There are a few moments that I'll remember fondly, like the "rock concert" or the part where Sarah and Barry join you. The game has some frustrating moments, but it's never too difficult if you take the time to learn the mechanics.

content:
Posted: January 30, 2016
												Game Name: Alan WakeGame Overall Score: 10/10Alan wake is an amazing horror survival game made by Remedy Entertainment. The game starts off with you being a successful writer and taking a trip with your wife to Bright falls to relax from novel writing. The game has a very unique story and interesting combat system, although it is repetitive since there are few enemy types in the game. It’s a fairly straight forward game, point your flashlight at the enemy, wait for its darkness shield to disappear and then fire away with one of your weapons (Revolver, Shotgun, Flare gun, etc.) until its destroyed. I also like how the game is not too futuristic or advanced, but more of an old-fashioned kind of a game. Nowadays most of the games that are produced and sold are way to futuristic, which makes the production of old-fashioned games rarer. The performance and quality are very realistic and makes you feel that you’re in the game. I also like how there are secret chests and supplies lying around which gives you more to explore in the game. Also the game has fairly easy keying binds and controls for the player.I would recommend this game to people that are looking for an old-fashioned, third-person, survival, and horror game. But the game in my option, lacks enemy diversity. But the mysterious story of Alan wake makes up for lack of enemy diversity.The ending of Alan Wake was shocking for me since it ended in cliff-hanger.  But I like the way they closed the story, because it has potential idea for DLCs or other games.Fun Fact: The Remedy team spent a lot of time in the pacific northwest, collecting reference photos and getting a sense of the geography and climate in the areas. The art director and the rest of the team drove about 2,000 miles around Astoria, North Bend, and outside of Seattle for almost two weeks gathering information for the creation of this game.

												This is one of those rare games where your imagination can be used to massively increase the gaming experience. Some here have described it as playing a Stephen King horror story and I have to agree. If you're a jaded player and go looking for faults, you'll find them in every game including this one, but the story driven gameplay is fantastic. Well that's my opinion.It is one of the most atmospheric games I've played and ranks in my small personal list of great games.Play alone, in the dark and with headphones. Engage your imagination and child-like fear of the dark, then feel your skin crawl as you play. Never did a lamp-post look so appealing. Enjoy.Note: For me, get the original and stick with it because the extra bonus levels and American nightmare just don't cut it at all. They don't have the same well written atmosphere to them and do nothing for the terrific ending of the first game.During the game listen to Alan Wakes' description of what makes a horror story feel real etc etc. If you get what he's saying then just stop at the end of the first game. When you think about it, it's a truly horrifying ending ;)

content:
Posted: February 6, 2016
												A real review.The missing tag for Alan Wake in it's discription is 'story driven'. Alan Wake is a story driven game. There are many good things about this game but it is the story that will compel you to finish it.The horror aspect is mixed into the gameplay and it works at the start as you nervously walk through a forest at night with the feeling you are being chased by axe weilding country folk. As the story progesses you will master the combat style of duelwielding a flash light and a gun to kill the 'darkness'. Once mastered you find yourself collecting heaps of ammo, flares, flashbangs etc, so much so that no matter what object the 'darkness' chooses to posses you will have more than enough to defend yourself and loosing some of that horror in the process.The gameplay is different than anything else i have played which straight away makes it fun. Visually, the world you are in is beautiful, dark, dangerous and mysterious. The sound is also very good. The game has a great atmosphere. But...The cutscenes and story are so so so much better than the level design and gameplay that you will reach a cutscene, learn more of this increasingly interesting and captivating story, you will be all excited to find out more when Alan somehow manages to fall back into a forest. A dark forest. You finally get to the next cutscene, awesome, more story but then Alan slips and falls into the forest. Cutscene, forest, cutscene, another ****ing forest. That is how i felt playing this game by the end. I was racing through the level to get to the next part in the story. The horror gameplay really takes a back seat maybe half way through the game.But the story is that good that you will want to keep playing. One last thing, there is one type of enemy that you come across , little spoiler...It is so annoying, runs super fast so you cant shine your flashlight on it until it attacks you. It runs all around so you dont know from which direction will it jump out of the darkness, sounds scary but it isn't. It takes so long to try attack you that you have to stand there for a few minutes waiting. It's frustrating. You will know this enemy as soon as you see him. If he takes too long to attck you just run to the next checkpoint and he will dissapear. Really stupid character.All in all, if you want an action game with non repetitve gameplay this game is NOT for you! If you want something different with a great story this game IS FOR YOU! I liked it accept for that one type of enemy, so stupid, shouldn't be in the game.

												Alan Wake is a survival horror/action game hybrid revolving around a writer, Alan Wake, and his fight to reclaim is wife from an unknown force called "the Dark Presence.The light is the core element of the title's gameplay: the light of your flashlight makes the enemies vulnerable to your more earthly attacks; cone of lights called "Safe Heavens" act as checkpoints and health dispensers; the light is the only thing capable of thwarting the Presence's progress.The survival horror elements of Alan Wake come into play in the enemies often overcrowding you and your need to save ammo and other useful items: to the point that you are better off just running away from pursuers to the next Save Heaven most of the time.Said gameplay,an overall very good, thrilling, atmospheric story and some severe cases of scenary porn make Alan Wake a charming title in its own right

content:
Posted: January 6
												This game is a good example of something that truely tested time and aged well. I played this game back when it first came out on the Xbox 360, and playing it again on PC not only brought back good memories, but also showed me that this game to this day is still fantastic. Graphically for the most part it is beautiful especially when it comes to the game's lighting, but there were some low res texture, some of the screens from TVs are a bit hard to see, foliage popped in at ridiculously low ranges when driving in some areas, and in one section there were some funky shadow problems even though I had the graphics settings set to as high as they will go. Technically, the game does run fine for the most part. I did encounter some slow down and very minor stutters, but only when it was very busy on screen with flare and flashbang effects, but other than outside of that it ran fine. The story will keep you on edge of what is happening with the mystery of the setting of the game, Bright Falls, and the curse that is on it and what is all happening with the character waking up from a car crash a week later after he tries to save his wife and not knowing what is going on. Gameplay is very innovative where you have to use lights to defeat your enemies. Flashlights and lanterns only get rid of the darkness that shields enemies so that you can kill them with guns, flares ward enemies off while getting rid of the darkness on them in a wider area, and flare guns, flashbangs, and giant lights will outright defeat enemies. There are a few variety of enemies, although not many. I really only count about 6 different enemies, normal enemies, tougher enemies, much tougher enemies, fast enemies, crows, and poltergeists, and while they do vary a bit like the tougher enemies can shrug off you using the light boost and fast enemies easily dart around an area and much harder to concentrate your flashlight on, they all pretty much require the same way to defeat them; get rid of the darkness in them with your flashlight or any sort of light source and then shoot them, unless you defeated them with a flaregun or flashbang or it is a crow or poltergeist to which they'll just immediately die after the darkness is gone from them. I honestly think that is this game's biggest fault, the combat, because it will get very repetitive very fast especially since each level lasts quite a while. The game does present itself as pretty challenging at times, while being as fair as possible. I do think that the way that some enemies can easily gang up and almost immediately drain your health bar without any kind of recovery was a bit cheap, but you are given resources to help keep this from happening. Speaking of difficulty, and this is just a small note on something for anyone who wants to play the game, I have not done any kind of searching about this nor do I remember if this was part of the original Xbox 360 release, but it does seem that the difficulties are a bit misleading in the game. The game has 3 total difficulties, Easy, Normal, and Nightmare. Now I played the game through Normal, but when I beat the game it says that I completed it on both Normal and Hard even though a Hard difficulty option is not showing up at all. I have a feeling that there is no Easy difficulty and Easy is actually Normal difficulty, Normal is Hard, and Nightmare is Nightmare. As mentioned earlier, levels do last quite a while, and even though the game is mostly linear, there is a great deal of exploration that can be done in each level, and you are rewarded for exploring the levels to find each of the game's hidden secrets rather it be hidden chests which you can find by shining your flast light on certain areas that will reveal yellow paint that show you where to go, manuscript pages which tie into the game's story, TVs that will broadcast a TV show called Night Springs which is sorta like The Twilight Zone or will show Alan thinking about the situation he is in, Radios that will give a bit of behind the scenes of what is happening at the time of the level, or give a bit of history to the game's town. The game also encourages a 2nd playthrough where some manuscript pages can only be found on Nightmare difficulty. There is however 2 other collectibles that are in the game for seemingly no reason other than achievement purposes, the coffee thermoses and can pyramids, which to my knowledge don't seem to unlock or do anything, they're just there. There is a good amount in the game that will be worth the purchase. There is a total of 6 levels in the game that make up the core main game, and it'll take about 8-10 hours if you decide to go off the beaten path a bit to find some of the secrets in the game, maybe around 6 hours if you decide to rush through and skip over the secret stuff. There is also 2 bonus levels which will give you around 2-4 extra hours. My main complaints about the game is that it seemed to drag on with how fast the gameplay becomes repetitive and the levels while explorable to extent, go on for a while. I can easily recommend this game if you're looking for a horror game that has a great story and will give you plenty to do. The gameplay will get old fast, but if you do not mind it, then this game is easy enough for me to say that I recommend a buy.

content:
Posted: November 27, 2016
												One of my favorite games of all time. It's like a Stephen King book come to life. It manages to be very scary by preying on your fear of the dark without resorting to cheap jumpscares. I definitely recommend you play it.The story is filled with suspense and mystery, it's super engaging. It's heavily inspired by Twin Peaks, so fans of the show take the time to spot some easter eggs and find some thermoses filled with some damn good coffee. The soundtrack is awesome too. The "light" combat system this game utilizes is pretty neat, and although people say it can get repetitive, I think it's fun enough that it doesn't detract from the game. This is also one of the few games where playing on a harder difficulty can make the game harder without making it needlessly frustrating.I will list a few cons, however. This version is a console port, and this really really shows on older end machines. Luckily, most PCs today should be able to play it no problem. I can run it on highest settings at 60FPS on my GTX670 no problem, but the game doesn't visually seem like it would require as advanced a GPU as it actually does. The aiming and walking may also seem a bit wonky, but that's also a consequence of it being a console port.Overall rating: 9.5/10. I absolutely love everything about this game, but I gotta take half a point off for the issues stemming from it being a console port.

It took the makers years to make (which included many delays), and there is clear evidence throughout the game that it was originally meant to be at least semi-open world rather than sectioned into levels. Once it did come out though, it heralded a new style of narrative with chapters played like episodes of a TV show, replete with visual summaries of the previous episode at the start of each of them. That desire to experiment with narrative in the game is easily the best part, and even though it's very heavily inspired by Stephen King, it's still a very original style for gaming and will keep you playing through even the dullest gameplay portions. And that's the main problem with Alan Wake, the gameplay. Now, that's not to say it's even that bad, it's actually pretty enjoyable and adds a lot of tension that really helps the game's atmosphere. The game even introduces new and interesting enemies for a while that keep you on your toes! But somewhere around the halfway point the game gets bored with introducing new gameplay elements, and of course shortly after that point you will too. The game really does start to drag towards the end, and if you're anything like me it will feel like a real grind to finish it and see what happens to the story. Aaaand then there's no satisfactory conclusion either. The game wants you to play the episodes that were released as DLC, but due to lukewarm reception (the game already got boring, and the DLC adds nothing while rewarding you with even less substantial story), they got cut short at just the 2. I should mention Alan Wake 2 is rumoured to be in the works, so there is that anyway.But to cut this short, Alan Wake is absolutely fantastic for half of the game, and then falls short towards the end. Despite this, it's frankly a must play for what it does right, so I recommend it for sure.
